name: Jeff Bezos & family
fact1: Amazon's chief Jeff Bezos is the first person with a net worth surpassing $150 billion in the 3 decades that Forbes has tracked the richest Americans.
fact2: He owns 16% of e-commerce colossus Amazon, which he founded in a garage in Seattle in 1994.

name: Bill Gates
fact1: With his wife Melinda, Bill Gates chairs the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, the world's largest private charitable foundation.
fact2: The foundation works to save lives and improve global health, and is working with Rotary International to eliminate polio.

name: Warren Buffett
fact1: Known as the "Oracle of Omaha," Warren Buffett is one of the most successful investors of all time.
fact2: Buffett runs Berkshire Hathaway, which owns more than 60 companies, including insurer Geico, battery maker Duracell and restaurant chain Dairy Queen.

name: Mark Zuckerberg
fact1: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has had a difficult 2018; the social network has been criticized for enabling the spread of hate speech and fake news.
fact2: In April 2018, he testified before Congress after it was revealed that Facebook shared users' data with political consulting firm Cambridge Analytica.

name: Larry Ellison
fact1: Larry Ellison cofounded software firm Oracle in 1977 to tap into the growing need for customer relationship management databases.
fact2: He gave up the Oracle CEO role in 2014 but still serves as chairman of the board and chief technology officer.

name: Larry Page
fact1: Larry Page sits at the helm of Alphabet, the parent company of Google, healthcare division Calico, smart home appliance division Nest and more.
fact2: He cofounded Google in 1998 with fellow Stanford Ph.D. student Sergey Brin.

name: Charles Koch
fact1: Charles Koch has been chairman and CEO of Koch Industries, America's second largest private company, since 1967.
fact2: The conglomerate has some $100 billion in revenues from businesses including pipelines, chemicals, Dixie cups, and Stainmaster carpets.

name: David Koch
fact1: David Koch shares majority control of Koch Industries, U.S's second largest private firm, with his brother Charles.
fact2: Koch stepped down from his role as executive vice president in July 2018, citing health concerns; he was named director emeritus.

name: Sergey Brin
fact1: Sergey Brin works as president of tech giant Alphabet, the parent firm of Google.
fact2: He previously ran the secretive Google X division, which made the ill-fated Google glasses.

name: Michael Bloomberg
fact1: Michael Bloomberg cofounded financial information and media company Bloomberg LP in 1981.
fact2: After putting down the company's seed funding, he has retained an 88% stake in the business, which has revenue north of $9 billion.

name: Jim Walton
fact1: Jim Walton is the youngest son of Walmart founder Sam Walton.
fact2: He runs the family's Arvest Bank, which boasts assets of more than $16 billion.

name: Alice Walton
fact1: Alice Walton is the only daughter of Walmart founder Sam Walton.
fact2: She has focused on curating art, rather than working for Walmart like her siblings, Rob and Jim.

name: Rob Walton
fact1: Rob Walton is the eldest son of Walmart founder Sam Walton.
fact2: He ran the retailer for nearly 25 years; he first took over as chairman upon his father's death in 1992.

name: Steve Ballmer
fact1: Steve Ballmer is the high-wattage former CEO of Microsoft, who led the company from 2000 to 2014.
fact2: He joined Microsoft in 1980 as employee No. 30 after dropping out of Stanford's MBA program.

name: Sheldon Adelson
fact1: Sheldon Adelson is the CEO and chairman of casino company Las Vegas Sands.
fact2: Today he owns more than half of the $13 billion (sales) gambling empire.

name: Phil Knight & family
fact1: Phil Knight, founder of shoe giant Nike, retired as chairman in June 2016 after 52 years at the company.
fact2: Knight ran track at the University of Oregon and created Nike with his former track coach Bill Bowerman.

name: Michael Dell
fact1: Michael Dell is the chairman and CEO of Dell Technologies, which was formed in 2016 when Dell merged with computer storage giant EMC.
fact2: The estimated $60 billion Dell-EMC merger, which was finalized in 2016, was the largest technology acquisition ever.

name: Jacqueline Mars
fact1: Jacqueline Mars owns an estimated one third of Mars, the world's largest candymaker.
fact2: Mars was founded by Jacqueline's grandfather, Frank, in 1911.

name: John Mars
fact1: John and his siblings Jacqueline and Forrest Jr. (died July 2016) inherited stakes in the candy firm Mars Inc. when their father died in 1999.
fact2: He and Jacqueline each own one third of the company, which is being run by some of their children.

name: Laurene Powell Jobs & family
fact1: Laurene Powell Jobs is the widow of Apple cofounder Steve Jobs.
fact2: She founded and chairs the Emerson Collective, an organization that uses entrepreneurship to advance social reform and to assist needy students.

name: Paul Allen
fact1: Paul Allen, who cofounded Microsoft with Bill Gates and later became a philanthropist and sports team owner, died on Oct. 15, 2018 at age 65.
fact2: Allen left Microsoft 8 years after cofounding the company in 1975 when he was diagnosed with Hodgkin's disease.

name: Thomas Peterffy
fact1: A digital trading pioneer, Thomas Peterffy is CEO of Interactive Brokers, which markets its specialized trading platform to sophisticated investors.
fact2: He founded Interactive Brokers in 1993 after originally starting in market-making.

name: Jim Simons
fact1: James Simons is the founder of Renaissance Technologies, a legendary quantitative hedge fund firm that manages $57 billion.
fact2: He founded Renaissance Technologies in 1982 and retired in 2010, but he still plays a role at Renaissance and benefits from its funds.

name: Elon Musk
fact1: Elon Musk is working to revolutionize transportation both on Earth and in space.
fact2: His automaker, Tesla Motors, which was founded in 2003, is bringing fully-electric vehicles to the mass market.

name: Ray Dalio
fact1: Ray Dalio is the founder of the world's biggest hedge fund firm, Bridgewater Associates, which manages $160 billion.
fact2: Working to make sure Bridgewater survives him, Dalio moved in 2018 to turn Bridgewater into a partnership and give employees more of a stake in the firm.

name: Rupert Murdoch & family
fact1: Rupert Murdoch controls a media empire that includes cable channel Fox News, The Times of London and The Wall Street Journal.
fact2: Murdoch, a native of Australia, inherited a newspaper at age 22 after his father, a former war correspondent, passed away.

name: Len Blavatnik
fact1: Born in Ukraine, raised north of Moscow, Len Blavatnik emigrated to the U.S. in 1978 for school; he studied computer science at Columbia University.
fact2: He is a dual citizen of the U.S. and the U.K.

name: Abigail Johnson
fact1: Abigail Johnson's grandfather, Edward Johnson II, founded mutual fund giant Fidelity Investments in 1946.
fact2: She has served as CEO since 2014, when she took over for her father Edward "Ned" Johnson III, and as chairman since 2016.

name: Harold Hamm & family
fact1: Fracking pioneer Harold Hamm runs Continental Resources, one of the nation's biggest independent oil companies.
fact2: The 13th child of Oklahoma sharecroppers, he picked cotton barefoot as a child and started working at a gas station at age 16 to support his family.

name: Donald Bren
fact1: Donald Bren is the country's richest real-estate developer.
fact2: His Irvine Co. owns over 115 million square feet of real estate, mostly in Southern California.

name: Carl Icahn
fact1: Carl Icahn is one of Wall Street's most successful investors and has been shaking up corporate America for decades.
fact2: Icahn is chairman of publicly-traded Icahn Enterprises, which had $8 billion of its assets in investments as of August 2018.

name: Lukas Walton
fact1: Lukas Walton is the grandson of Walmart founder Sam Walton.
fact2: He inherited his fortune when his father, John Walton, died in a 2005 plane crash.

name: Eric Schmidt
fact1: After 17 years, Eric Schmidt stepped down in Jan. 2018 as executive chairman of Google's parent company, Alphabet; he will now be a technical advisor.
fact2: Shortly after stepping down, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology announced that Schmidt would be joining as a visiting innovation fellow.

name: Stephen Schwarzman
fact1: The son of a dry goods store owner, Stephen Schwarzman founded private equity firm Blackstone with fellow billionaire Peter Peterson in 1985.
fact2: Initially a boutique merger-and-acquisition advisory business, Blackstone grew into the world's largest buyout firm, with $439 billion in assets.

name: Leonard Lauder
fact1: Leonard Lauder spent three decades running his family's publicly traded cosmetics giant. He stepped down as CEO in 1999 but remains chairman emeritus.
fact2: The eldest son of the eponymous makeup maven, Lauder joined his mother's company in 1958.

name: Steve Cohen
fact1: Steve Cohen oversees Point72 Asset Management, a $13 billion hedge fund firm that started managing outside capital in 2018.
fact2: For years Cohen ran SAC Capital, one of the most successful hedge funds ever.

name: Thomas Frist, Jr. & family
fact1: Thomas Frist Jr., a former Air Force flight surgeon, founded Hospital Corp. of America with his father in 1968.
fact2: He took it public for the third time in 2011 after two management buyouts.

name: Pierre Omidyar
fact1: Pierre Omidyar founded online auction firm eBay in 1995 and now serves on the company's board.
fact2: Omidyar has slowly been whittling down his stakes in both eBay and its former subsidiary PayPal; he still owns about 7% of eBay.

name: David Tepper
fact1: David Tepper, arguably the greatest hedge fund manager of his generation, has been steadily returning money to client investors in recent years.
fact2: Tepper's Appaloosa Management hedge fund firm now manages $15 billion and is based in Miami Beach, Florida.

name: Philip Anschutz
fact1: Over five decades Philip Anschutz has built fortunes in oil, railroads, telecom, real estate and entertainment.
fact2: He owns the NHL's Kings and a third of the Lakers, plus the building they play in, the Staples Center.

name: John Menard, Jr.
fact1: John Menard's home improvement retailer brings in an estimated $10 billion in sales from over 300 stores.
fact2: His stores, which compete with Home Depot and Lowe's, are concentrated in the middle of the U.S., spanning from Wyoming to Ohio.

name: Donald Newhouse
fact1: Donald Newhouse and his brother, Samuel "Si" inherited the publishing and broadcasting empire Advance Publications decades ago.
fact2: Donald is president of Advance Publications and oversees the newspaper business that his father Sam built up from the daily The Staten Island Advance.

name: Dustin Moskovitz
fact1: Dustin Moskovitz helped launch Facebook in 2004 with then-roommate Mark Zuckerberg from their Harvard dorm.
fact2: After leaving the social network in 2008, he cofounded Asana, a workflow software company; most of his net worth is from his 3% stake in Facebook.

name: Charles Ergen
fact1: Charlie Ergen is the cofounder and chairman of satellite TV provider Dish Network and satellite communications company EchoStar.
fact2: Ergen first began selling satellite dishes out of the back of a truck in Colorado in 1980.

name: Ken Griffin
fact1: Ken Griffin founded and runs Citadel, a Chicago-based hedge fund that manages $30 billion in assets.
fact2: He founded Citadel in 1990 but first began trading from his Harvard dorm in 1987. He put a satellite dish on the roof to get real-time stock quotes.

name: Andrew Beal
fact1: Andrew Beal is the founder and sole owner of Beal Financial Corporation, which has assets of more than $7 billion.
fact2: The Texas banker is known for gobbling up distressed assets, including mortgages, bonds backed by commercial planes and IOUs to power plants.

name: David Duffield
fact1: David Duffield founded not just one, but two successful enterprise software companies after age 40.
fact2: He started PeopleSoft at 47 and sold it to Oracle for $10.7 billion in cash in 2005.

name: Jan Koum
fact1: Jan Koum cofounded WhatsApp, now the world's biggest mobile messaging service, in 2009.
fact2: Facebook bought the startup for $22 billion in cash and stock in 2014.

name: Micky Arison
fact1: Micky Arison is chairman of the world's largest cruise ship operator, Carnival Corp.
fact2: He spent 34 years as CEO of Carnival, helping grow its fleet from two ships to more than 100, before stepping down in June 2013.

name: Gordon Moore
fact1: Silicon Valley pioneer Gordon Moore cofounded semiconductor firm Intel in 1968; he had previously cofounded Fairchild Semiconductor.
fact2: Moore is famous for his prediction that computer processing power would double every year, an insight known as "Moore's Law."

name: Ronald Perelman
fact1: Ronald Perelman is a consummate dealmaker who built a fortune with a diverse array of holdings, from candy to cosmetics.
fact2: He earned a reputation in the 1980s as one of the era's fiercest corporate raiders.

name: Jim Kennedy
fact1: Jim Kennedy is the chairman of privately-held automotive and media company Cox Enterprises; he shares ownership with his sister and cousins.
fact2: He served as CEO from 1988 to 2008; under his leadership revenues rose from $1.8 billion to $15.4 billion.

name: Blair Parry-Okeden
fact1: Blair Parry-Okeden inherited a 25% stake in Cox Enterprises in 2007 when her mother, Barbara Cox Anthony, died.
fact2: Cox Enterprises is a $20.1 billion (sales) automotive and media company based in Atlanta; it owns cable TV firm Cox Communications.

name: Charles Schwab
fact1: Charles Schwab is chairman and founder of the eponymous brokerage firm, which manages $3.6 trillion worth of assets.
fact2: He was CEO of the company until 2008, and remains the largest shareholder with a 11% stake.

name: James Goodnight
fact1: James Goodnight cofounded the analytics software firm SAS in 1976 with John Sall, whom he met while a PhD student at North Carolina State University.
fact2: Goodnight has been at the helm since the company's inception, when its software was developed to analyze agricultural data.

name: David Geffen
fact1: Hollywood's richest man is the co-founder/founder of record labels Asylum Records, Geffen Records and DGC Records, as well as film studio DreamWorks.
fact2: Born to Jewish immigrants in Brooklyn, Geffen started his career in the mailroom of talent agency William Morris, where he rose to become an agent.

name: Edward Johnson, III.
fact1: After a stint in the Army, Edward "Ned" Johnson III became an analyst at money manager Fidelity, which his dad founded in 1946.
fact2: Ned led Fidelity as CEO for 37 years; his daughter Abigail replaced him in 2014.

name: Stanley Kroenke
fact1: Stan Kroenke is a real estate and sports mogul. He owns some 30 million square feet of real estate, much of it shopping plazas near Walmart stores.
fact2: He is married to Walmart heiress Ann Walton-Kroenke, niece of the retailer's founder Sam Walton.

name: Carl Cook
fact1: Carl Cook took over as CEO of his parents' medical device manufacturer, Cook Group, when his father Bill died in 2011.
fact2: The $2 billion (sales) company sold one of its subsidiaries Cook Pharmica to drug delivery technology company Catalent for $950 million in 2017.

name: Herbert Kohler, Jr. & family
fact1: Herbert Kohler Jr. is the executive chairman of Kohler, the Wisconsin-based plumbing fixture manufacturer that bears his family's name.
fact2: He stepped down as CEO in 2015 after running the company for 43 years but remains chairman. His son David is the CEO.

name: George Soros
fact1: George Soros is a legendary hedge fund tycoon who managed client money in New York from 1969 to 2011.
fact2: In 1992, Soros shorted the British pound and reportedly made a profit of $1 billion. He became known as the man who broke the Bank of England.

name: George Kaiser
fact1: In the 1930s Kaiser's parents fled Nazi Germany and settled in Tulsa, Oklahoma.
fact2: George took over Kaiser-Francis Oil Company in the 1960s.

name: John Doerr
fact1: Investor John Doerr is chairman of venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers.
fact2: The 66-year-old joined the investment firm in 1980 after working at Intel and cofounding two companies.

name: Pauline MacMillan Keinath
fact1: Pauline MacMillan Keinath is believed to be the largest shareholder of Cargill, the largest food company in the world, with an estimated 12% stake.
fact2: Her brother Whitney MacMillan was the last member of the family to serve as CEO of the business, but he retired in 1995.

name: Shahid Khan
fact1: An engineer by trade, Shahid Khan bought auto parts supplier Flex-N-Gate from his former employer in 1980.
fact2: His design for a one-piece truck bumper was the basis for his success; the company now has 64 plants worldwide and over 24,000 employees.

name: Stephen Ross
fact1: Stephen Ross, chairman of Related Companies, is the developer behind America's largest private real estate project.
fact2: His $25 billion mega-development, Hudson Yards, opened its first building in 2016. Five more will open in 2018 and 2019. It will be completed by 2024.

name: John Malone
fact1: Nicknamed the Cable Cowboy, John Malone is known for his penchant for media deals and complicated corporate structures.
fact2: From the 1970s to the 1990s, Malone built up cable TV firm TCI as right hand man to founder Bob Magness (d. 1996).

name: Hank & Doug Meijer
fact1: Brothers Hank and Doug Meijer stepped down as co-chairmen of grocery chain Meijer in 2017. Both remain on the company's board of directors.
fact2: The brothers took over the family-owned company from their father, Frederik, in 1990.

name: Patrick Soon-Shiong
fact1: Patrick Soon-Shiong invented cancer drug, Abraxane. It became a blockbuster thanks to its efficacy against pancreatic cancer.
fact2: He sold drug companies Abraxis and American Pharmaceutical Partners for a combined $9.1 billion.

name: Christy Walton
fact1: Christy Walton married into what became the richest family in the world: Walmart's Walton clan.
fact2: She inherited her fortune when her husband, John Walton, died in a 2005 plane crash.

name: Daniel Gilbert
fact1: Dan Gilbert cofounded what would become Quicken Loans, the largest online mortgage lender, in 1985.
fact2: He sold it to Intuit for $532 million in 1999, but bought it back 3 years later for $64 million.

name: Ralph Lauren
fact1: Ralph Lauren is executive chairman and chief creative officer of Ralph Lauren, his all-American fashion empire. He controls 82% of the voting rights.
fact2: Lauren started the business in 1967 in a tiny office at the Empire State building. His first breakthrough came when Neiman Marcus ordered 1,200 ties.

name: David Green & family
fact1: A preacher's son from a poor background, Hobby Lobby founder David Green opened his first crafts shop in 1970 with a $600 loan.
fact2: His empire has grown from a single 300-square-foot store in Oklahoma City to over 800 locations in 47 states, with more than $4 billion in sales.

name: Tom & Judy Love
fact1: Tom and Judy Love are the founders of convenience store chain Love's Travel Stops & Country Store.
fact2: They started their company in 1964 when they leased a gas station in Watonga, Oklahoma for $5,000.

name: Jerry Jones
fact1: The former co-captain of the University of Arkansas 1964 national championship team, Jerry Jones has long had football in his blood.
fact2: Jones made a name for himself as an oil wildcatter and still invests in drilling opportunities, retail and residential real estate projects in Dallas.

name: Leon Black
fact1: Leon Black is the cofounder, chairman and CEO of private equity behemoth Apollo Global Management, which manages $269 billion in assets.
fact2: He spent much of his early career at investment bank Drexel Burnham Lambert, where he eventually headed the mergers and acquisitions group.

name: Diane Hendricks
fact1: Diane Hendricks chairs ABC Supply, one of the largest wholesale distributors of roofing, siding and windows in America.
fact2: Hendricks cofounded the business with her late husband, Ken, in Beloit, Wisconsin, 36 years ago. She has run it since his death in 2007.

name: Eli Broad
fact1: Eli Broad bought his first real estate at age 20 and cofounded home builder Kaufman & Broad in 1957 with $25,000 borrowed from his in-laws.
fact2: KB Homes became one of the nation's biggest home builders, supplying parents of baby boomers with affordable housing.

name: Jensen Huang
fact1: Jensen Huang cofounded graphics-chip maker Nvidia in 1993, and has served as its CEO and president since inception.
fact2: Born in Taiwan, Huang moved to Thailand as a child, but his family sent him and his brother to the U.S as civil unrest mounted in the Asian nation.

name: Richard Kinder
fact1: Kinder chairs oil and gas pipeline giant Kinder Morgan, the largest U.S. energy infrastructure firm, which owns or operates 84,000 miles of pipeline.
fact2: He cofounded Kinder Morgan in 1997 after stepping down as president of energy and commodities firm Enron Corp.

name: Robert Kraft
fact1: Robert Kraft bought the New England Patriots for $172 million in 1994 and has grown it to a $3.7 billion team with five Super Bowl wins in 15 years.
fact2: His fortune stems from a paper-manufacturing conglomerate, which includes the Rand-Whitney Group.

name: John A. Sobrato & family
fact1: Real estate mogul John A. Sobrato began selling homes in Palo Alto while he was still a student at Santa Clara University.
fact2: He later worked with his mother to develop industrial properties, and founded his own real estate company in 1979.

name: Ann Walton Kroenke
fact1: Ann Walton-Kroenke is the daughter of Bud Walton, who helped his brother, Sam, build Walmart into a retail giant.
fact2: She inherited part of Bud's stake in the retailer when he died in 1995.

name: Marc Benioff
fact1: Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff owns about 5% of the cloud computing software firm he cofounded in 1999.
fact2: Before Salesforce, he spent 13 years at database software giant Oracle as a protege of Larry Ellison.

name: Jack Dorsey
fact1: Tattooed entrepreneur Jack Dorsey has been CEO of both social media firm Twitter and small business payments company Square since 2015.
fact2: Dorsey cofounded Twitter in 2006 with Ev Williams, Biz Stone and Noah Glass, and was CEO until 2008. He returned in 2015.

name: Whitney MacMillan
fact1: Whitney MacMillan was the last member of the Cargill-MacMillan family to serve as CEO of Cargill, America's largest private company, retiring in 1995.
fact2: His great-grandfather, W.W. Cargill, founded the business as a single grain warehouse on the end of an Iowa railroad line in 1865.

name: David Shaw
fact1: A former computer science professor at Columbia University, David Shaw is the founder of D.E. Shaw, which manages over $50 billion in assets.
fact2: Known for its use of sophisticated mathematical modeling and algorithms, the quantitative hedge fund firm was founded in 1988.

name: Dannine Avara
fact1: Dannine Avara and her three siblings inherited Enterprise Products Partners, the energy pipeline giant founded by their late father, Dan Duncan.
fact2: Formerly the richest person in Houston, Duncan died in 2010 at age 77 of a brain hemorrhage.

name: James Chambers
fact1: James Cox Chambers inherited an estimated 17% stake in media and automotive conglomerate Cox Enterprises from his mother Anne Cox Chambers.
fact2: His grandfather, James M. Cox, founded what became Cox Enterprises in 1898.

name: Scott Duncan
fact1: Scott Duncan and his three older siblings each inherited a stake in their father Dan Duncan's pipeline firm, Enterprise Products Partners, in 2010.
fact2: Founded in 1968, the company owns natural gas processing plants, oil and gas storage facilities and about 50,000 miles of oil and gas pipelines.

name: Milane Frantz
fact1: Milane Duncan Frantz's father, Dan Duncan, founded Houston-based pipeline giant Enterprise Products Partners in 1968 and took it public in 1998.
fact2: Frantz and her three siblings inherited a stake in the company after their dad died in 2010; only Randa Duncan Williams is involved in the business.

name: John Paulson
fact1: John Paulson made his fortune betting against subprime mortgages at the peak of the 2007 credit bubble.
fact2: His hedge fund firm, Paulson & Co., was started in 1994 and enjoyed success as a niche fund until Paulson put on his "big short."

name: Steven Rales
fact1: Steven Rales and his brother Mitchell acquired a REIT in 1983 and merged their profitable acquisitions into the firm, called Danaher.
fact2: Focused on tax avoidance and cash flow, they acquired more than three dozen companies and turned Danaher into a firm with $20 billion in revenue.

name: Katharine Rayner
fact1: Katharine Rayner  inherited an estimated 17% stake in media and automotive conglomerate Cox Enterprises from her mother, Anne Cox Chambers.
fact2: Cox Enterprises, a private company started by Rayner's grandfather, has some $20 billion in revenues; it has a cable TV arm, TV stations and more.

name: Margaretta Taylor
fact1: Margaretta Taylor inherited an estimated 17% stake in media and automotive conglomerate Cox Enterprises from her mother, Anne Cox Chambers.
fact2: Her grandfather, James M. Cox, founded what has become Cox Enterprises in 1898.

name: Dennis Washington
fact1: Dennis Washington parlayed an early love of machinery into a diversified business group called Washington Companies.
fact2: Washington bought Dominion Diamond for $1.2 billion in November 2017. He already owns a copper mine and regional railroads.

name: Randa Williams
fact1: Randa Duncan Williams is non-executive chairman of Enterprise Products Partners, the pipeline giant her father Dan Duncan (d. 2010) founded in 1968.
fact2: Williams is the only one of four siblings involved in running the family business; all four inherited equal stakes in the company.

name: Israel Englander
fact1: Israel Englander founded Millennium Management in 1989 with $35 million. Now, the hedge fund firm manages more than $35 billion.
fact2: Israel Englander, or Izzy, is the son of Polish immigrants.

name: Richard LeFrak & family
fact1: Richard LeFrak became CEO of the LeFrak Organization in 2003 when his father Sam died.
fact2: The father-son team transformed the business, which started in France in 1883, into one of the largest real estate developers in the New York area.

name: Marijke Mars
fact1: Marijke Mars and her three sisters are heirs to the family's giant candy and pet food company, Mars Inc.
fact2: She inherited her estimated 8% stake in the company when her father, Forrest Mars Jr., died in 2016.

name: Pamela Mars
fact1: Pamela Mars is an heir to her family's candy and pet food fortune.
fact2: She and her three sisters each inherited an estimated 8% stake in Mars Inc. when their father, Forrest Mars Jr., died in 2016.

name: Valerie Mars
fact1: Valerie Mars and her three sisters each inherited an estimated 8% stake in candymaker Mars Inc. when their father, Forrest Mars Jr., died in 2016.
fact2: Her great-grandfather Frank Mars founded the company in 1911.

name: Victoria Mars
fact1: Victoria Mars and her three sisters are heirs to the family's giant candy and pet food company, Mars Inc.
fact2: She inherited her estimated 8% stake in the company when her father Forrest Mars Jr. died in 2016.

name: Jim Davis & family
fact1: Jim Davis bought a small Boston shoemaker in 1972 and turned it into New Balance, which reaped $4 billion in 2017 sales.
fact2: Davis and his family own an estimated 95% of the company, which is private.

name: Travis Kalanick
fact1: Kalanick, who founded ride-hailing firm Uber in 2009, stepped down as CEO in June 2017 after a series of scandals rocked the company.
fact2: In March 2018, Kalanick announced a new venture fund, 10100, which combines his nonprofit and for-profit investments.

name: Reinhold Schmieding
fact1: Michigan native Reinhold Schmieding started Arthrex, an orthopedic surgical tools company, in 1981 in Munich, Germany.
fact2: Arthrex is now headquartered in Naples, Florida and has developed over 12,500 products used in shoulder, hip and other joint surgeries.

name: Henry Kravis
fact1: Henry Kravis cofounded private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis & Roberts with his cousin, George Roberts, and Jerome Kohlberg (d. 2015) in 1976.
fact2: In 1989, KKR orchestrated the $25 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco; the deal became the basis of the bestselling book "Barbarians at the Gate."

name: Robert Rowling
fact1: In 1996 he reinvested $500 million from selling the family's oilfields into the purchase of Omni Hotels.
fact2: The Omni chain has 60 locations and 21,000 rooms nationwide with big new hotels in Dallas, Atlanta and Boston.

name: Charles Dolan & family
fact1: Cable pioneer Charles Dolan owns controlling stakes in AMC Networks and Madison Square Garden.
fact2: Dolan sold Cablevision, the cable giant he launched in 1973 with 1,500 customers, to billionaire Patrick Drahi's Altice for $17.7 billion in 2016.

name: Nancy Walton Laurie
fact1: Nancy Walton-Laurie inherited a stake in Walmart from her father, Bud Walton, who helped his brother, Sam, build the retail giant.
fact2: When Bud died in 1995, Walton-Laurie and her sister, Ann Walton-Kroenke, received enough Walmart stock to make them both billionaires.

name: Bernard Marcus
fact1: Bernard Marcus was fired from hardware store Handy Dan in 1978, along with his coworker Arthur Blank, so the duo started a rival retailer, Home Depot.
fact2: In 1981, Marcus, Blank and early investor Kenneth Langone took Home Depot public. All three men are now billionaires.

name: John Morris
fact1: John Morris is founder and CEO of outdoor gear retailer Bass Pro Shops.
fact2: Morris started the company in 1972 by selling fish tackle from the back of his father's liquor store in Springfield, Missouri.

name: George Roberts
fact1: George Roberts is cofounder and co-CEO of private equity giant KKR & Co. and a pioneer in the leveraged buyout business.
fact2: Along with his cousin Henry Kravis and their mentor Jerome Kohlberg, the three led KKR through debt-financed hostile takeovers starting in the 1970s.

name: Stewart and Lynda Resnick
fact1: From almonds & oranges in California's Central Valley to grapefruits in South Texas, Stewart & Lynda Resnick owe their billions to nature's bounties.
fact2: Nearly half of all Americans purchase one of their products, including Halos mandarin oranges, POM Wonderful and Fiji Water.

name: Edward Roski, Jr.
fact1: Through his Majestic Realty, Los Angeles-based developer Edward Roski Jr., owns more than 78 million square feet of real estate across the country.
fact2: Majestic Realty is developing a 441-acre business park on the site of Pennsylvania's former Bethlehem Steel plant.

name: Ronda Stryker
fact1: Ronda Stryker is a director of Stryker Corp., the medical equipment company founded by her grandfather, Homer Stryker (d. 1980).
fact2: She inherited a stake in Stryker Corp. from her parents and is the only one of her siblings to serve on the board.

name: Sam Zell
fact1: In 1969 Sam Zell started Equity Group Investments, which today invests in energy, logistics, transportation, manufacturing, communications and healthcare.
fact2: Zell's Equity International has invested in 15 emerging markets including Argentina, where it's co-investing $300 million with Goldman Sachs.

name: Bubba Cathy
fact1: Bubba Cathy and his brother, Dan, run fast-food juggernaut Chick-fil-A, the fried chicken chain founded by their father, Truett (d. 2014), in 1967.
fact2: He grew up in the business, rising from construction apprentice to senior vice president in 1995.

name: Dan Cathy
fact1: Fried chicken billionaire Dan Cathy is chairman and CEO of Chick-fil-A, the fast-food juggernaut his father, Truett Cathy (d. 2014), founded in 1967.
fact2: He grew up doing odd jobs in his father's restaurants, including scraping chewing gum from table bottoms with a butter knife.

name: Martha Ingram & family
fact1: Martha Ingram and her family own distribution and marine firm Ingram Industries.
fact2: Ingram took over the business after her husband Bronson Ingram died in 1995.

name: John Overdeck
fact1: John Overdeck is the co-founder of Two Sigma Investments, a quantitative trading powerhouse with $54 billion under management.
fact2: Two Sigma is a data-driven hedge fund that absorbs large amounts of information to predict the prices of securities.

name: David Siegel
fact1: David Siegel is the co-founder of Two Sigma Investments,a quantitative trading powerhouse that manages $54 billion.
fact2: Two Sigma is a data-driven hedge fund that absorbs large amounts of information to predict the prices of securities.

name: George Lucas
fact1: 'Star Wars' creator George Lucas has largely retired from filmmaking since he sold his Lucasfilm to Disney in 2012 for $4.1 billion in stock and cash.
fact2: Lucas is now focused on philanthropy: his charitable family foundation is already endowed with more than $1 billion.

name: Fred Smith
fact1: FedEx founder Fred Smith came up with the idea for the company for a term paper at Yale in 1965.
fact2: After graduation, Smith served in Vietnam with the Marines. He returned home and launched FedEx in 1971.

name: David Sun

name: John Tu
fact1: Kingston Technology president John Tu helps run the firm, which makes storage and memory products, from a cubicle on sales floor.
fact2: With longtime partner David Sun, Tu launched a computer memory business out of a garage and sold it to now defunct PC maker AST a few years later.

name: Ernest Garcia, II.
fact1: Ernest Garcia is the biggest shareholder of Carvana, an online platform for selling used cars and making auto loans that conducted an IPO in 2017.
fact2: Garcia also owns and runs DriveTime Automotive, the nation's fourth-biggest used car retailer.

name: Ray Lee Hunt
fact1: Ray Lee Hunt is the wealthiest of legendary oil wildcatter H.L. Hunt's 15 children.
fact2: He chairs Hunt Consolidated, an oil and gas, electric power, real estate and investing conglomerate.

name: Robert Pera
fact1: Robert Pera is the founder and CEO of wireless equipment maker Ubiquiti Networks.
fact2: Ubiquiti, which had $865 million in fiscal 2017 revenues, sells wireless broadband systems with a focus on emerging markets.

name: Trevor Rees-Jones
fact1: Rees-Jones started as a bankruptcy attorney, but wanted to make deals, not clean up after them.
fact2: In 1984 he started Chief Oil & Gas and became a pioneer of the shale fracking boom.

name: Bruce Kovner
fact1: Bruce Kovner is chairman of CAM Capital, founded in 2012, which manages his personal investment and business portfolios.
fact2: Kovner is the founder and chairman of Caxton Associates, a global macro hedge fund.

name: Sheldon Solow
fact1: Sheldon Solow risked everything in 1972 to build 9 West 57 Street in New York City, the tower that's known for its unobstructed views of Central Park.
fact2: Its current tenants include KKR, Apollo Global Management, Tiger Global Management and Chanel.

name: Karen Pritzker
fact1: Karen Pritzker is one of 11 billionaire Pritzker heirs. Her grandfather, A.N. Pritzker, built industrial conglomerate Marmot and the Hyatt hotels.
fact2: She has invested in public companies like Apple as well as hundreds of private biotech and medical device firms.

name: Robert Bass
fact1: In 1959 Robert Bass and his brothers inherited $2.8 million each from their oil tycoon uncle Sid Richardson.
fact2: Robert has helped launch a half dozen investment shops including his Oak Hill Advisors.

name: Charles Johnson
fact1: Charles Johnson is the largest shareholder in Franklin Resources, a global investment management firm also called Franklin Templeton Investments.
fact2: Johnson became CEO at age 24 in 1957, a decade after his father, Rupert Johnson Sr., founded the company.

name: Arthur Blank
fact1: Arthur Blank and Bernie Marcus cofounded Home Depot in 1978 after being fired from their jobs at a regional hardware store.
fact2: Blank stepped down as co-chairman of Home Depot in 2001 and the next year bought the NFL's Atlanta Falcons for $545 million (now worth $2.1 billion).

name: Ted Lerner & family
fact1: In 1952, a 26-year-old Ted Lerner borrowed $250 from his wife to start a real estate company, selling homes for developers.
fact2: He sold some 22,000, then decided to become a builder. Now he owns 20 million square feet of commercial and retail space, plus hotels and apartments.

name: Gwendolyn Sontheim Meyer
fact1: Gwendolyn Sontheim Meyer inherited an estimated 7% stake in food giant Cargill, the largest private company in America.
fact2: The heiress spends most of her time on a farm in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., training horses that compete in show jumping.

name: J. Christopher Reyes
fact1: Chris Reyes and his brother Jude co-chair Reyes Holdings, a $30 billion (sales) food and beverage distribution company.
fact2: The company started by their father with a small Schlitz beer distributor in South Carolina purchased for $740,000 in 1974.

name: Jude Reyes
fact1: Together Jude Reyes and his brother Chris run Reyes Holdings, a $30 billion (sales) food and beverage distribution company.
fact2: Their father started the company with a small Schlitz beer distributor in South Carolina purchased for $740,000 in 1974.

name: Robert Rich, Jr.
fact1: Frozen food mogul Robert Rich, Jr. leads Rich Products, founded by his father, Robert Rich Sr. (d. 2006) in 1945.
fact2: The company made its mark with the first non-dairy whipped cream and expanded into non-dairy frozen foods.

name: Kelcy Warren
fact1: Kelcy Warren cofounded pipeline company Energy Transfer with Ray C. Davis (now also a billionaire) in 1995.
fact2: Warren's fortune stems from stakes in three publicly traded companies; Energy Transfer Equity LP, Energy Transfer Partners LP and Sunoco LP.

name: Stanley Druckenmiller
fact1: Stanley Druckenmiller made it big as a hedge fund manager for 30 years. He now manages his money through a family office.
fact2: Until 2000, he worked for George Soros. The duo famously bet against the British pound in 1992 and made massive profits.

name: Sumner Redstone
fact1: Sumner Redstone remains controlling shareholder of both CBS and the beleaguered Viacom, despite continuous boardroom and courtroom drama.
fact2: Redstone's father founded the cinema chain now known as National Amusements in 1936; Redstone took over in 1954.

name: Leonard Stern
fact1: Leonard Stern joined his father Max's pet supply business in 1959. Seven years later he expanded into real estate, acquiring a New Jersey warehouse.
fact2: His Hartz Mountain firm owns over 42 million square feet of real estate, mostly in the New Jersey area.

name: Daniel Ziff
fact1: Daniel Ziff and his brothers Robert and Dirk inherited a fortune launched in 1927 when their grandfather cofounded publishing company Ziff Davis.
fact2: Daniel's late father, William Jr., built up Ziff Davis, published PC Magazine and Car and Driver, and sold the company for $1.4 billion in 1994.

name: Dirk Ziff
fact1: Dirk Ziff and his brothers Robert and Daniel inherited a fortune launched in 1927 when their grandfather cofounded publishing company Ziff Davis.
fact2: The brothers' late father built up Ziff Davis, publisher of PC Magazine and Car and Driver, and sold the company for $1.4 billion in 1994.

name: Robert Ziff
fact1: Like his brothers Dirk and Daniel, Robert Ziff, the middle billionaire child, owes his fortune to his grandfather's publishing company, Ziff Davis.
fact2: The brothers' late father, William Jr., built up Ziff Davis, published PC Magazine and Car and Driver, and sold the company for $1.4 billion in 1994.

name: Les Wexner & family
fact1: Les Wexner founded and runs L Brands, a global retail empire that includes Victoria's Secret and Bath & Body Works.
fact2: One of America's longest-serving CEOs, he has served as the company's CEO since founding the business more than five decades ago.

name: David Filo
fact1: David Filo is cofounder of Yahoo, a onetime web service behemoth, which sold its core business to Verizon for $4.48 billion in cash in June 2017.
fact2: The most valuable part of Yahoo - its 15% stake in Alibaba and its 35% stake in Yahoo Japan - morphed into a listed company called Altaba.

name: Tamara Gustavson
fact1: With an 11% stake, Tamara Hughes Gustavson is Public Storage's largest shareholder. Her father, B. Wayne Hughes, cofounded the storage giant in 1972.
fact2: She joined the firm in 1983 and rose to vice president before leaving in 2003 to raise her children. She returned four years later as a board member.

name: Jeff Skoll
fact1: Jeff Skoll built his fortune as eBay's first full-time hire and president in 1995; he left eBay in 2001, three years after its IPO.
fact2: Skoll divides his time between his Skoll Foundation, which funds social entrepreneurs, and film production firm Participant Media.

name: Austen Cargill, II.
fact1: Austen Cargill II is one of 14 billionaire heirs to Cargill, the family business where he served as a vice president until retiring in 2001.
fact2: His great-grandfather, W.W. Cargill, founded the business as a single grain warehouse on the end of an Iowa railroad line in 1865.

name: James Cargill, II.
fact1: James Cargill is one of 14 billionaire heirs to Cargill, America's largest private company.
fact2: His great-grandfather, W.W. Cargill, founded the business as a single grain warehouse on the end of an Iowa railroad line in 1865.

name: Dagmar Dolby & family
fact1: Dagmar Dolby owns about 38% of publicly-traded audio technology firm Dolby Laboratories, which her husband Ray Dolby (d. 2013) founded in 1965.
fact2: The company pioneered surround sound technologies used in thousands of films and products, and most recently, in video games and mobile devices.

name: Tilman Fertitta
fact1: Tilman Fertitta is the owner of the Houston Rockets. The NBA approved the $2.2 billion purchase by Fertitta in October 2017.
fact2: Fertitta also owns the Golden Nugget Casinos and Landry's, a Texas-based restaurant and entertainment company.

name: Paul Tudor Jones, II.
fact1: Hedge fund manager Paul Tudor Jones II is known for his macro trades, particularly his bets on interest rates and currencies.
fact2: In 1980, he founded Tudor Investment Corporation, which had a long record of double-digit annualized returns.

name: Marianne Liebmann
fact1: Marianne Liebmann is one of 14 billionaire heirs to Cargill, America's largest private company.
fact2: Her great-grandfather, W.W. Cargill, founded the business as a single grain warehouse on the end of an Iowa railroad line in 1865.

name: Terrence Pegula
fact1: Terry Pegula made a fortune in fracking and has since turned it into a sports empire that includes the Buffalo Bills and Buffalo Sabres.
fact2: His oil and gas outfit, East Resources, sold the bulk of its assets to Royal Dutch Shell for $4.7 billion in 2010.

name: Gary Rollins
fact1: Billionaire brothers Randall and Gary Rollins preside over Orkin, the biggest pest control company by revenues in North America.
fact2: The bug-killing business is booming: in April 2017, the company reported its 44th consecutive quarter of sales and earnings growth.

name: Walter Scott, Jr. & family
fact1: Walter Scott Jr, lifelong friend of Warren Buffett, owes the bulk of his fortune to Berkshire Hathaway Energy, Buffett's massive utilities subsidiary.
fact2: In 2000, Scott and Buffett partnered to buy utility MidAmerican Energy, later renamed Berkshire Hathaway Energy, for $2 billion.

name: Russ Weiner
fact1: Russ Weiner founded energy drink company Rockstar in 2001, striking gold by marketing an energy drink in a tall-boy can.
fact2: Weiner started Yachak Organic in late 2017 as a natural alternative to Rockstar. Profits will go to protect endangered species and the environment.

name: Nick Caporella
fact1: Nick Caporella, a onetime contractor and the son of a Pennsylvania coal miner, founded National Beverage Co. in 1985.
fact2: Then the CEO of telecom and cable company Burnup & Sims, Caporella started the soft drinks firm to fend off famed corporate raider Victor Posner.

name: Randall Rollins
fact1: Randall Rollins is chairman of Rollins Inc.,the biggest pest control company by revenues in North America. His brother Gary is CEO.

name: John Sall
fact1: John Sall cofounded statistical software firm SAS with James Goodnight in 1976.

name: Richard Schulze
fact1: Richard Schulze founded Sound of Music in 1966, which he eventually transformed into a chain of superstores and renamed it Best Buy.
fact2: Schulze served as the company's CEO from 1983 to 2002 and stepped down as chairman in 2012, when a scandal erupted around his hand-picked CEO.

name: Robert F. Smith
fact1: Robert Smith founded private equity firm Vista Equity Partners in 2000. It focuses exclusively on investing in software companies.
fact2: With over $30 billion in assets, Vista is one of the best-performing private equity firms, posting annualized returns of 22% since inception.

name: Stephen Bisciotti
fact1: Steve Bisciotti is the cofounder of Allegis Group, the world's largest private staffing firm.
fact2: He started the business with his cousin, and fellow billionaire, Jim Davis. Allegis now brings in $12.3 billion in annual revenue.

name: Isaac Perlmutter
fact1: Isaac "Ike" Perlmutter beat out fellow billionaire Carl Icahn for control of bankrupt comic book firm Marvel in 1998; he serves as the chairman.
fact2: He revived the company's stock by producing action-hero movies like Spiderman, Daredevil, Hulk and Iron Man.

name: Julian Robertson, Jr.
fact1: Notable trader Julian Robertson helped pioneer the modern day hedge fund industry; he founded Tiger Management in 1980.
fact2: Since closing his fund in 2000, Robertson has been managing his own book and has seeded several funds started by his disciples, dubbed Tiger Cubs.

name: Jeff Sutton
fact1: King of Manhattan storefronts, Jeff Sutton commands some of the highest rents in the country with pricey leases to such brands as Armani and Escada.
fact2: In spring 2018, his Wharton Properties and partner SL Green signed Puma to open a new, 24,000 square feet flagship store at 609 Fifth Avenue.

name: Jeremy Jacobs, Sr.
fact1: Jeremy Jacobs is chairman of concessions juggernaut Delaware North, a private company that serves 500 million people per year across four continents.
fact2: The business was founded in 1915 by his father, who began by selling popcorn and peanuts. The company now has annual revenue of about $3 billion.

name: Rupert Johnson, Jr.
fact1: Rupert Johnson Jr. is the vice chairman of Franklin Resources, a global investment management firm also called Franklin Templeton Investments.
fact2: He is the second largest shareholder in the firm with 19.2%, after his half brother Charles who chaired the company until 2013.

name: H. Ross Perot, Sr.
fact1: Ross Perot quit IBM to found Electronic Data Systems in 1962. He netted $1.5 billion selling it to G.M. in 1986.
fact2: He ran for president in 1992 and 1996, while treating Americans to half-hour long primetime infomercials on how he intended to fix the economy.

name: Thomas Pritzker
fact1: Tom Pritzker, one of 11 billionaire heirs in the Pritzker clan, serves as the executive chairman of hotel giant Hyatt.
fact2: Hyatt Hotels dates back 1957 when Tom's father, Jay Pritzker (d. 1999), purchased the first Hyatt House motel near Los Angeles International Airport.

name: Frank VanderSloot
fact1: Frank VanderSloot founded and runs Melaleuca, which makes more than 400 products ranging from health supplements to eco-friendly household cleaners.
fact2: Melaleuca sells them direct from the factory to more than one million consumers every month through its online store.

name: Jack Dangermond
fact1: Jack Dangermond founded Esri, the industry leader in GIS technology, a specialized software used for creating digital maps.
fact2: He founded the company in 1969 with $1,100 in personal savings.

name: Igor Olenicoff
fact1: Russian immigrant Igor Olenicoff fled the Soviet Union with his family at age 15, and eventually built up a substantial real estate empire.
fact2: His Olen Properties owns 8 million square feet of office space and 12,000 residential units in California and four other U.S. states.

name: Ben Ashkenazy
fact1: Ben Ashkenazy bought his first building at age 17, after he went to a Bronx  shopping center to check out a site to open a fast food restaurant.

name: Bert Beveridge
fact1: Bert "Tito" Beveridge is the founder of Tito's Vodka.

name: Neil Bluhm

fact2: Bluhm also owns a number of the largest casinos in the Midwest, like the Rivers Casinos and SugarHouse Casino.

name: Rick Caruso
fact1: Rick Caruso is a Los Angeles real estate developer who has built some of the country's most successful shopping centers.
fact2: One of those centers, The Grove, gets an average of 49,000 daily visitors -- more than Disneyland.

name: Archie Aldis Emmerson & family
fact1: The country's third largest landowner, Archie Aldis "Red" Emmerson and his family own nearly 2 million acres.
fact2: His Sierra Pacific Industries is the largest private lumber production firm in the nation with 15 sawmills across California and Washington.

name: Dan Friedkin
fact1: Dan Friedkin owns Gulf States Toyota, which sold $9 billion worth of Toyotas in 2017.
fact2: The company, based in Houston, has exclusive rights to distribute Toyota vehicles in Texas, Arkansas, Louisiana, Mississippi and Oklahoma.

name: Jeffery Hildebrand
fact1: Jeffrey Hildebrand cofounded Hilcorp in 1990; he later bought out his partner for $500 million.
fact2: Former Exxon geologist has specialized in reinvigorating old oil and gas fields like in the Gulf of Mexico and Alaska.

name: Marian Ilitch
fact1: Marian Ilitch and her husband, Mike, who died in February 2017, cofounded Little Caesars Pizza in 1959.
fact2: Mrs. I, as she's known, now owns the pizza chain, which hauls in more than $4 billion in annual systemwide sales.

name: James Leprino
fact1: James Leprino owns the world's largest mozzarella cheese maker with $3.5 billion in estimated annual sales.
fact2: His Leprino Foods exclusively sells to cheese to Domino's, Papa John's and Pizza Hut.

name: Jerry Speyer
fact1: Real estate baron Jerry Speyer developed landmarks like Rockefeller Center and the Chrysler Building in Manhattan.
