name: Steven Udvar-Hazy
fact1: Steven Udvar-Hazy, who immigrated to New York from Budapest, Hungary as a child, is credited with creating the airplane leasing industry.
fact2: He started his own airline in his 20s, but realized there was easier money to be made in buying planes and leasing them to airlines.

name: Mark Cuban
fact1: Mark Cuban cofounded video portal Broadcast.com with fellow Indiana University alum Todd Wagner in 1995.
fact2: Today he owns the NBA's Dallas Mavericks and has stakes in Landmark Theaters, Magnolia Pictures and AXS TV.

name: Tom Gores
fact1: Tom Gores oversees more than 25 companies with some $13 billion in assets through his Los Angeles-based private equity firm, Platinum Equity.
fact2: The Gores family moved from Israel to Michigan when Tom was four. In his youth, he stocked shelves at his father's small grocery store in Flint.

name: Edward Johnson, IV.
fact1: Edward Johnson IV is the grandson of Edward Johnson II, who founded Fidelity Investments in 1946.
fact2: He is the brother of current Fidelity CEO and Chairman Abigail Johnson.

name: Elizabeth Johnson
fact1: Elizabeth Johnson is the granddaughter of Edward Johnson II, who founded Fidelity Investments in 1946.
fact2: She is the sister of current Fidelity CEO and Chairman Abigail Johnson.

name: Ronald Lauder
fact1: Ronald Lauder is the youngest son of makeup maven Estee Lauder, who founded her eponymous beauty company in 1946.
fact2: He became the chairman of Clinique Laboratories in 1994 and still occupies that position today.

name: Gabe Newell
fact1: Gabe Newell has led Valve Corp., which develops video games, since he cofounded it in 1998 with former Microsoft colleague Mike Harrington.
fact2: The company found initial success with games like Half-Life and Portal.

name: Henry Samueli
fact1: Henry Samueli is co-founder and Chief Technology Officer of chipmaker Broadcom.
fact2: Samueli cofounded Broadcom with Henry Nicholas in 1991. It was acquired by Avago Technology in 2016 for $37 billion and renamed itself Broadcom Ltd.

name: Alejandro Santo Domingo
fact1: Alejandro Santo Domingo, public face of the Santo Domingo clan, sits on the board of beer giant Anheuser-Busch, in which he has a 1.7% stake.
fact2: Santo Domingo was a key negotiator in the deals that led to the 2016 merger between Anheuser-Busch and SABMiller.

name: Andres Santo Domingo
fact1: Andres Santo Domingo inherited a part of his father Julio Mario Santo Domingo's massive stake in the beer giant SABMiller when he died in 2011.
fact2: The bulk of his fortune is now in Anheuser-Busch InBev, following its $100 billion merger with SABMiller in 2016.

name: Harry Stine
fact1: Farm boy turned seed-genetics savant Harry Stine has made a fortune licensing corn and soybean genetics to multinationals like Monsanto and Syngenta.
fact2: Stine founded and runs Stine Seed; his current obsession is tinkering with seed genetics that allow for better yields or pesticide resistance.

name: Rocco Commisso
fact1: Rocco Commisso is the founder and CEO of cable company Mediacom, based in Chester, New York.
fact2: He previously worked as CFO at Cablevision Industries, which was acquired by Time Warner in 1995.

name: Ken Fisher
fact1: Fisher is executive chairman and co-chief investment officer of Fisher Investments, which he founded in 1979 with $250.
fact2: The firm had assets under management of approximately  $96 billion in 2017, up from $72 billion a year earlier.

name: Peter Kellogg
fact1: Peter Kellogg sold brokerage house Spear, Leeds & Kellogg to Goldman Sachs for $6.5 billion in cash and stock in 2000.
fact2: Kellogg joined the firm, where his father was a partner, in 1973 and took over several years later.

name: Douglas Leone
fact1: Doug Leone is the managing partner at venture capital firm Sequoia Capital, which operates in China, India, Israel and the U.S.
fact2: Leone guided Sequoia into tech investments including Medallia, Rackspace, RingCentral and ServiceNow.

name: Robert McNair
fact1: Robert "Bob" McNair, the owner of the NFL's Houston Texans, died the day after Thanksgiving 2018 at the age of 81.
fact2: McNair is survived by his wife, 4 children, 15 grandchildren and 2 great grandchildren.

name: Ira Rennert
fact1: Ira Rennert is the founder of the Renco Group, an industrial empire that claims to have revenues of over $5 billion annually.
fact2: Renco's holdings include a stake in military truckmaker AM General, lead and zinc producer Doe Run Company, and U.S. Magnesium Corp., among others.

name: Bernard Saul, II.
fact1: B. Francis Saul II inherited his grandfather's property management firm, B.F. Saul Company, and turned it into a real estate empire.
fact2: B.F. Saul Company owns 9.2 million square feet of retail and office space across the country along with 21 hotels.

name: Nathan Blecharczyk
fact1: Nathan Blecharczyk cofounded peer-to-peer room and home rental company Airbnb with Joe Gebbia and Brian Chesky in 2008.
fact2: Blecharczyk, who is chief strategy officer, was the company's first engineer.

name: Brian Chesky
fact1: Brian Chesky cofounded peer-to-peer room and home rental company Airbnb with Nathan Blecharczyk and Joe Gebbia in 2008.
fact2: Chesky is CEO of Airbnb, which has been used by more than 300 million people in 81,000 cities in 191 countries.

name: Joe Gebbia
fact1: Joe Gebbia cofounded peer-to-peer room and home rental company Airbnb with Brian Chesky and Nathan Blecharczyk in 2008.
fact2: Gebbia and Chesky met in college at Rhode Island School of Design.

name: Joshua Harris
fact1: Joshua Harris cofounded private equity powerhouse Apollo Global Management in 1990 with fellow billionaires Leon Black and Marc Rowan.
fact2: The trio met at investment bank Drexel Burnham Lambert, and struck out on their own after the troubled firm filed for bankruptcy.

name: Ken Langone
fact1: In 1978, Kenneth Langone made an early investment in Home Depot and became a cofounder with Arthur Blank and Bernard Marcus, now billionaires.
fact2: The grandson of Italian immigrants, Langone dug ditches for the Long Island Expressway before he went to Bucknell University to study economics.

name: Michael Milken
fact1: Mike Milken joined what became investment bank Drexel Burnham Lambert in 1969 and expanded the market for high-yield junk bonds.
fact2: He was banned from the securities industry for life after pleading guilty to a securities fraud charge in 1990.

name: Mitchell Rales
fact1: Mitchell Rales and his brother Steven acquired a real estate investment trust in 1983 and merged it into the firm Danaher.
fact2: Over the years they acquired more than three dozen companies and turned Danaher into an industrial firm with $20 billion in revenues.

name: Steven Spielberg
fact1: The three-time Academy Award winner scored his best box office tally in two decades with 'Ready Player One,' a sci-fi romp that grossed $582 million.
fact2: His Amblin Partners (formerly DreamWorks Studios) notched a production credit on the hit and has a spate of new projects on the way.

name: Brian Acton
fact1: Computer engineer Brian Acton cofounded messaging app WhatsApp with Jan Koum in 2007; the two had met while working at Yahoo.
fact2: The pair sold WhatsApp to Facebook for $22 billion in cash and stock in 2014.

name: Clifford Asness
fact1: Cliff Asness is the co-founder of AQR Capital Management, a fast-growing money management firm that oversees $225 billion.
fact2: AQR stands for Applied Quantitative Research. It focuses on factor-based investing, offering products ranging from hedge funds to mutual funds.

name: John Brown
fact1: John Brown ran Stryker Corp., a medical device and software company, for 32 years before retiring as chairman in 2009.
fact2: Stryker's revenues climbed from $17 million to $6.7 billion under Brown's leadership. He led the IPO of Stryker in 1979.

name: Barry Diller
fact1: Barry Diller founded internet and media conglomerate IAC in 1995 where he's senior executive and chairman.
fact2: Diller is also chairman of travel tech company Expedia which spun off from IAC in 2005. He has a 3.4% stake in Expedia.

name: Reed Hastings
fact1: Reed Hastings, cofounder and CEO of Netflix, revolutionized how the world watches its entertainment.
fact2: Hastings founded Netflix in 1995, the same year he sold his first company, Pure Software, to Rational Software.

name: Min Kao & family
fact1: Min Kao is executive chairman of $3.1 billion (sales) navigation firm Garmin, which makes everything from GPS for cars to weather radar for airplanes.
fact2: Min Kao cofounded GPS maker Garmin with Gary Burrell in 1989, after the duo led development of the first GPS navigator at Allied Signal.

name: Joe Mansueto
fact1: Joe Mansueto started financial information company, Morningstar, in 1984 with $80,000 in savings.
fact2: In January 2017 Mansueto stepped down as CEO after more than 30 years at the helm.

name: Donald Sterling
fact1: The Chicago native, born Donald Tokowitz to Jewish immigrants, built a fortune largely by buying down-at-the-heels apartment buildings in Los Angeles.
fact2: Donald Sterling bought the Clippers in 1981 for $12.5 million when the team was based in San Diego. Three years later he moved it to Los Angeles.

name: Scott Cook
fact1: Scott Cook is the cofounder of financial software giant Intuit, known for products like QuickBooks, TurboTax and Mint.
fact2: The Harvard Business School grad worked for Procter & Gamble and Bain before launching Intuit in 1983.

name: Judy Faulkner
fact1: Judy Faulkner founded America's leading medical-record software provider, Epic, in a Wisconsin basement in 1979.
fact2: Faulkner, a computer programmer, is still CEO of the $2.7 billion (2017 sales) company.

name: Tom Golisano
fact1: Tom Golisano founded payroll giant Paychex in 1971 with just $3,000 and a credit card.
fact2: He served as CEO until 2004 and remains chairman of the publicly-traded company.

name: H. Fisk Johnson
fact1: H. Fisk Johnson III is the chairman and CEO of SC Johnson, a privately-held cleaning products company.
fact2: He is the fifth generation of the Johnson family to lead the company.

name: S. Curtis Johnson
fact1: S. Curtis is a great-great-grandson of Samuel Curtis Johnson, who founded SC Johnson, the family's cleaning products company, in 1886.
fact2: In 2014, he was sentenced to four months in jail and fined $6,000 after pleading guilty to misdemeanor sexual assault of his stepdaughter.

name: Helen Johnson-Leipold
fact1: Helen Johnson-Leipold is an heir to family-owned SC Johnson,  the privately-held cleaning products company.
fact2: Helen is the chairman and CEO of Johnson Outdoors, a publicly-traded company that sells outdoor gear.

name: Winifred Johnson-Marquart
fact1: Winifred Johnson-Marquart is the president of the Johnson Family Foundation
fact2: The Johnson Family Foundation focuses on the environment and community issues such as early education and infant mortality.

name: Rodger Riney
fact1: Rodger Riney founded the discount brokerage firm Scottrade in 1980 in Scottsdale, Arizona with a partner whom he bought out in 1985.
fact2: Riney, who has served as CEO, expanded the firm; it has 3 million client accounts with a total $170 billion in assets under management.

name: Mark Walter
fact1: Mark Walter is CEO of investment firm Guggenheim Partners, which has some $265 billion in assets under management.
fact2: Walter helped found the firm in the late 1990s after he folded his Chicago-based company, Liberty Hampshire, into the Guggenheim family office.

name: Sid Bass
fact1: Sid Bass inherited several million dollars from his oil tycoon great-uncle Sid Richardson in 1959. He's been diversifying ever since.
fact2: Bass has nurtured the careers of famed investors like Richard Rainwater.

name: Charles Cohen
fact1: Real estate developer Charles Cohen bought out his father and uncle and quadrupled business to 12 million square feet.
fact2: Most of his fortune is in high end office buildings in New York City and design centers in several cities.

name: Jeff Greene
fact1: Jeff Greene became a billionaire by buying credit default swaps on subprime mortgage-backed bonds as housing crashed.
fact2: Most of his fortune is now held in equities and other investments plus real estate in Los Angeles and Palm Beach.

name: Amos Hostetter, Jr.
fact1: Amos Hostetter Jr. made a fortune in the 1990s as cable TV pioneer and now is most active in philanthropy.
fact2: He set out with an MBA and $1,500 in the 1960s to invest in a cable TV company that eventually became Continental Cablevision.

name: Michael Moritz
fact1: Wales native Michael Moritz got his start as a journalist at Time Magazine after emigrating to America in 1976.
fact2: Moritz wrote an early biography of Steve Jobs and Apple, "The Little Kingdom," while Time's San Francisco bureau chief.

name: Henry Nicholas, III.
fact1: Henry Nicholas III and business partner Henry Samueli cofounded fabless semiconductor firm Broadcom in 1991 in a Redondo Beach, Calif. condominium.
fact2: In February 2016 Broadcom was acquired by Singapore-based chip firm Avago for $37 billion in cash and stock and renamed Broadcom Ltd.

name: David Steward
fact1: David Steward is the cofounder and chairman of IT provider World Wide Technology.
fact2: In 1990, he put up $250,000 he earned from two previous auditing ventures to start the St. Louis-based business.

name: John Arnold
fact1: John Arnold shocked the hedge fund world in 2012 when, at just 38 years old, he announced he would no longer manage other people's money.
fact2: A hugely successful energy trader, Arnold once worked at Enron, earning the disgraced company a reported $750 million the year it went bankrupt.

name: David Bonderman
fact1: David Bonderman is chairman and founding partner of private equity giant TPG, which has $84 billion in assets under management.
fact2: "Bondo" met his longtime business partner Jim Coulter while working for billionaire Robert Bass. The pair left in 1992 to found TPG.

name: Leon G. Cooperman
fact1: A Wall Street legend, Leon Cooperman built up Goldman Sachs' asset management division, GSAM, in his quarter century with the investment bank.
fact2: Cooperman founded Omega Advisors in 1991, a hedge fund known for strong performance; he is shutting down the fund at the end of 2018.

name: Allan Goldman
fact1: Allan Goldman co-chairs America's most valuable family-run real estate portfolio with his younger sister Jane.
fact2: The two took over the business' leadership when their father Sol, a legendary real estate investor, died in 1987.

name: Jane Goldman
fact1: Jane Goldman is America's only female billionaire running a real estate firm. She heads up Solil Management, which she owns with her three siblings.
fact2: The youngest daughter of Sol Goldman (d. 1987), once New York's biggest landlord, she oversees a portfolio that includes at least 400 properties.

name: Amy Goldman Fowler
fact1: Real estate heiress Amy Goldman Fowler is one of four siblings who equally split ownership of Solil Management, which owns 400 properties.
fact2: Amy is the second-youngest daughter of late patriarch Sol Goldman. His trademark was all-cash deals whenever possible.

name: Diane Kemper
fact1: Real estate heiress Diane Kemper is one of four Goldman siblings who co-own Solil Management, which owns at least 400 properties in New York City.
fact2: Trophies include retail and office space along Madison Avenue in midtown and high-end coops on the Upper East Side.

name: Vincent McMahon
fact1: Vince McMahon is chairman and CEO of entertainment company World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE), which hauls in nearly $1 billion in annual revenue.
fact2: A third generation wrestling promoter, McMahon grew up in a trailer park in North Carolina and joined his father's small wrestling company in 1972.

name: Jay Paul
fact1: Silicon Valley real estate developer Jay Paul builds and leases office space to big tech firms, including Hewlett-Packard, Amazon and Apple.
fact2: His privately held Jay Paul Co. developed some 11 million square feet of office space and has 6 million more in the pipeline, mostly in Sunnyvale, Ca.

name: Anthony Pritzker
fact1: Anthony "Tony" Pritzker and his brother JB Pritzker own The Pritzker Group, a private equity and venture capital firm.
fact2: The Pritzker Group owns and runs industrial firms, particularly in the packaging sector. It also has a stake in Elon Musk's rocket firm SpaceX.

name: Lynn Schusterman
fact1: Lynn's husband Charles Schusterman founded Samson Resources in 1971 and grew it until his death from leukemia in 2000.
fact2: She sold the company to a KKR-led group for $7.2 billion in 2011.

name: Meg Whitman
fact1: Meg Whitman is best known for taking eBay from $5.7 million to $8 billion in sales as CEO from 1998 to 2008.
fact2: She was CEO of Hewlett-Packard from 2011 to 2015, when she oversaw its split into HP Inc. and Hewlett Packard Enterprise.

name: John Middleton
fact1: John Middleton made his fortune selling his family's storied tobacco business to Philip Morris-parent Altria for $2.9 billion in cash in 2007.
fact2: The original business, John Middleton Inc., was founded as a small retail tobacco shop in Philadelphia in 1856 by his great-great-grandfather.

name: J.B. Pritzker
fact1: Jay Robert "JB" Pritzker, an heir to the Hyatt Hotel fortune, ran private equity firm Pritzker Group with his brother Anthony until March 2017.
fact2: The Pritzker Group owns and runs industrial firms, particularly in the packaging sector. It also has a stake in Elon Musk's rocket firm SpaceX.

name: Jean (Gigi) Pritzker
fact1: One of 11 billionaire heirs to the Hyatt Hotels fortune, Jean "Gigi" Pritzker is now a movie producer based in Los Angeles.
fact2: In 2015 she founded Madison Wells Media, a diversified media & entertainment company that includes a virtual reality division.

name: Marc Rowan
fact1: Marc Rowan is the cofounder of Apollo Global Management, one of the biggest U.S. private equity firms, with $269 billion in assets.
fact2: A UPenn alum, Rowan met Apollo cofounders Leon Black and Joshua Harris while working at investment bank Drexel Burnham Lambert's M&A division.

name: Mark Shoen
fact1: Mark Shoen owns roughly one-fifth of U-Haul parent company Amerco through a limited partnership called Willow Grove.
fact2: Mark is also owner of one of the largest private self-storage operations in the U.S., which does business with U-Haul.

name: Herb Simon
fact1: In 1960, Herb Simon and his brother Melvin (d. 2009) founded the precursor to Simon Property Group.
fact2: Simon Property is now one of the world's largest REITs, with 179 shopping malls covering 153 million square feet across America, Europe and Asia.

name: Paul Singer
fact1: Hedge fund magnate Paul Singer is known for his high-profile, and often combative, dealmaking.
fact2: He founded his hedge fund firm, Elliott Management, in 1977 with $1.3 million. The firm now has some $35 billion in assets under management.

name: Jon Stryker
fact1: Jon Stryker's grandfather founded Stryker Corp., which sold $12.4 billion in medical equipment and software in 2017.
fact2: He is president and founder of the Arcus Foundation, which supports the advancement of LGBT human rights and the conservation of great apes.

name: Riley Bechtel & family
fact1: Riley Bechtel ran Bechtel, his family's construction and engineering firm, from 1990 to 2014.
fact2: He stepped down as CEO in 2014 after being diagnosed with Parkinson's disease.

name: Stephen Bechtel, Jr.
fact1: Stephen Bechtel, Jr. ran Bechtel, his family's construction and engineering firm, for 30 years, from 1960 to 1990.
fact2: Today his grandson, Brendan Bechtel, is CEO and chairman of the $32.9 billion (sales) company.

name: John Catsimatidis
fact1: John Catsimatidis is best known as the owner of New York City supermarket chain Gristedes.
fact2: He also owns oil refinery United Refining in Pennsylvania, which he bought out of bankruptcy, and real estate in New York and beyond.

name: Don Hankey
fact1: The little-known king of subprime car loans, Don Hankey presides over the $1.7 billion (sales) Hankey Group, a Los Angeles-based auto services empire.
fact2: His Westlake Financial Services works with more than 25,000 car dealerships in all 50 states to provide car loans to people with bad, or no, credit.

name: Johnelle Hunt
fact1: In 1961, Johnelle Hunt and her late husband, J.B. (d. 2006), sold their home and took out loans to start a rice hull packaging operation.
fact2: Eight years later, the couple bought five trucks and seven trailers to launch J.B. Hunt Transport Services.

name: Daniel Loeb
fact1: Dan Loeb is the founder of Third Point, a hedge fund that manages some $18 billion.
fact2: Loeb is known for launching activist campaigns against corporate boards, shaking up companies in various industries and countries.

name: Mary Alice Dorrance Malone
fact1: Mary Alice Dorrance Malone is the largest shareholder of the Campbell Soup Company.
fact2: She sits on Campbell's board alongside her billionaire brother, Bennett Dorrance.

name: Daniel Och
fact1: Dan Och is the founder of Och-Ziff Capital Management, a publicly traded hedge fund firm that oversees $33 billion.
fact2: In 2018, Och relinquished the chief executive position at Och-Ziff, which named former banker Robert Shafir as CEO.

name: Richard Sands
fact1: Richard and Robert Sands' father, Marvin, founded a humble wine business in 1945 at age 21.
fact2: That small operation has ballooned into a publicly traded behemoth now called Constellation Brands, which generates over $7 billion in annual revenue.

name: Robert Sands
fact1: Richard and Robert Sands' father, Marvin, founded a humble wine business in 1945 at age 21.
fact2: That small operation has ballooned into a publicly traded behemoth now called Constellation Brands, which generates over $7 billion in annual revenue.

name: Donald Trump
fact1: Donald Trump became the first billionaire president in U.S. history in January 2017.
fact2: The core of his fortune is tied up in a half-dozen buildings in and around midtown Manhattan in New York City, where luxury real estate values have fallen recently.

name: Don Vultaggio & family
fact1: Arizona Beverages cofounder Don Vultaggio has built his fortune one 99-cent tallboy can of iced tea at a time.
fact2: He got his start in the 1970s selling beer and soda from the back of an old van in Brooklyn's toughest neighborhoods, where others refused to go.

name: James Jannard
fact1: Jim Jannard founded sunglasses empire Oakley out of his car in 1975. His first product was a motorcycle grip that wicked sweat during long rides.
fact2: It went public in 1995 and sold to Luxottica for $2.1 billion in 2007.

name: Randal Kirk
fact1: Randal Kirk, a former practicing attorney, is the chief executive of biotech conglomerate Intrexon.
fact2: He achieved his first entrepreneurial success with an injectable drug and vaccine distributor, which eventually sold for $145 million.

name: Joseph Liemandt
fact1: Joe Liemandt is the founder of ESW Capital, an investment firm that purchases software companies.
fact2: Liemandt is known for founding Trilogy Software, a product and sales configuration software company that was prominent in the 1990s.

name: Arturo Moreno
fact1: Arturo Moreno is the owner of the Los Angeles Angels baseball team, which he bought in 2003 for $184 million. It is now worth $1.8 billion.
fact2: Moreno's initial fortune came from billboard advertising company Outdoor Systems, which he sold to Infinity Broadcasting for $8.7 billion in 1999.

name: Michael Rubin
fact1: Michael Rubin is the majority owner and CEO of Kynetic, which is the holding company for e-commerce retailers Fanatics, Rue La La and ShopRunner.
fact2: His flash-sales site, Rue La La, acquired longtime rival Gilt Groupe for an undisclosed price in June 2018.

name: Eric Smidt
fact1: Eric Smidt was a teenager when he started Harbor Freight Tools with his father Allan in 1977. He graduated high school through a work study program.
fact2: In the beginning, Harbor Freight was a mail-order business that sold tools out of a small shop in North Hollywood.

name: Lynsi Snyder
fact1: Lynsi Snyder is the heir to beloved West Coast chain In-N-Out Burger, which her grandparents founded in 1948.
fact2: She became a billionaire in 2017 on her 35th birthday, when she received the final portion of her inheritance.

name: Romesh T. Wadhwani
fact1: Romesh Wadhwani is the chairman and CEO of Symphony Technology Group, which brings in $2.5 billion in annual revenues.
fact2: He combined 9 of his companies that were AI-focused into a new group called SymphonyAI in 2017.

name: Steve Wynn
fact1: Casino magnate Steve Wynn created some of Las Vegas' most notable landmarks, including The Mirage, Treasure Island, Bellagio and Wynn Las Vegas.
fact2: He resigned as Wynn Resorts' chairman and CEO in February 2018 after dozens of women accused him of sexual misconduct.

name: Jim Breyer
fact1: One of Facebook's first venture investors, Jim Breyer made much of his fortune investing in the social network.
fact2: Breyer is brother-in-law of Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and his wife, U. S. Secretary of Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao.

name: William Conway, Jr.
fact1: William Conway Jr. is one of three billionaire founders of private equity firm Carlyle Group.
fact2: Conway stepped down as co-CEO in January 2018 and now serves as co-executive chairman with cofounder and billionaire David Rubenstein.

name: Daniel D'Aniello
fact1: Daniel D'Aniello is one of three billionaire founders of private equity firm Carlyle Group.
fact2: He stepped down as chairman in January 2018 and now serves as chairman emeritus of Carlyle, which has $210 billion in assets under management.

name: Jim Davis
fact1: Jim Davis is cofounder of Allegis Group, the world's largest privately-held staffing company.
fact2: He founded Allegis (then called Aerotek) in 1983 with his cousin Steve Bisciotti, who is also a billionaire.

name: Edward DeBartolo, Jr.
fact1: While most of his wealth comes from real estate, shopping mall magnate Edward Debartolo Jr. is best known as one of the most successful NFL owners.
fact2: Under Debartolo's ownership, the San Francisco 49ers won five championships during the 1980's and 1990's.

name: Gerald Ford
fact1: Gerald Ford has been buying distressed banks and turning them around since 1975, when he bought his first bank.
fact2: His first big success was in 2002, when he and his billionaire friend Ronald Perelman sold Golden State Bancorp to Citigroup for $6 billion in stock.

name: Jonathan Gray
fact1: Jonathan Gray started at asset manager Blackstone Group fresh out of college in 1992 and later rose to head the firm's vaunted real estate group.
fact2: Under Gray, Blackstone's real estate investments became one of its most valuable portfolios, with $120 billion in assets.

name: B. Wayne Hughes
fact1: B. Wayne Hughes cofounded Public Storage in 1972 and has since made a fortune storing Americans' excess junk.
fact2: The $2.6 billion (sales) company is the world's largest self-storage business, with more than 2,300 locations throughout the U.S. and Europe.

name: Jane Lauder
fact1: Jane Lauder is the granddaughter of cosmetics legend Este Lauder and now runs the makeup company's Clinique unit, a mall-staple skin-care line.
fact2: Lauder joined Estee Lauder in 1996, a year after graduating from Stanford. Before Clinique, she managed Origins, maker of all-natural makeup.

name: David Rubenstein
fact1: David Rubenstein is one of three billionaire founders of private equity firm Carlyle Group; he now serves as executive co-chairman.
fact2: Rubenstein got his start as a Carter Administration official and later became an attorney.

name: Patrick Ryan
fact1: Patrick Ryan is CEO and founder of Chicago based Ryan Specialty Group, a wholesale brokerage and specialty insurance firm.
fact2: His first brokerage, Ryan Insurance Co., merged with Combined Insurance Co. in 1982 to form AON, one of the largest insurance firms today.

name: Haim Saban
fact1: Haim Saban turned success with children's TV show Mighty Morphin Power Rangers into Fox Family Channel, a joint venture with News Corp.
fact2: Saban, who bought the franchise back in 2010, sold Power Rangers for a second time in 2017, this time to Hasbro in a $522 million deal.

name: Howard Schultz
fact1: Howard Schultz took charge of Starbucks in the 1980s and turned a regional coffee company into one of the world's top brands.
fact2: Schultz expanded Starbucks from 11 stores to more than 28,000 worldwide and made it a social hub for many Americans.

name: Thomas Siebel
fact1: Thomas Siebel's software company C3IoT raised about $100 million from private equity investors in January 2018, at a $1.5 billion valuation.
fact2: The company, which was initially started as a clean energy firm, is chasing the lucrative Internet of Things market, adding IoT to its name in 2016.

name: Charles Simonyi
fact1: Early Microsoft employee Charles Simonyi is the man behind some of the company's most successful software, including Word and Excel.
fact2: The developer has a Ph.D. in computer science from Stanford, and worked on one of the first personal computers at Xerox.

name: Glen Taylor
fact1: Glen Taylor bought a wedding service business for $2 million in 1975 and turned it into Taylor Corp., a printing firm with $2.2 billion in sales.
fact2: Taylor, who worked at the wedding business throughout college, stepped down as CEO of Taylor Corp. in 2015; he remains chairman.

name: William Wrigley, Jr.
fact1: In 1999 William "Beau" Wrigley Jr., an heir to the Wrigley's chewing gum fortune, took over the business his great-grandfather started in 1891.
fact2: Wrigley Jr., who was CEO, expanded the company in 2005 by purchasing Altoids and Life Savers from Kraft Foods for $1.46 billion.

name: Mortimer Zuckerman
fact1: Real estate icon Mortimer Zuckerman stepped down as Boston Properties chairman in May 2016, ending nearly 5 decades running the REIT.
fact2: Zuckerman became a U.S. citizen in 1977, and took Boston Properties public two decades later, in June 1997.

name: Gayle Benson
fact1: Gayle Benson is the widow of Tom Benson (d. March 2018), former owner of the NFL New Orleans Saints and NBA New Orleans Pelicans.
fact2: She is now the owner of both teams, despite a multi-year dispute with Tom's daughter and grandchildren over control of family assets.

name: John Fisher
fact1: John Fisher is the youngest of Gap founders Doris and Donald Fisher's three sons.
fact2: He was appointed to Gap's board of directors in October 2018. His brothers Robert and William also sit on the board.

name: Richard Peery
fact1: Early Silicon Valley property baron Richard "Dick" Peery partnered with John Arrillaga, buying farmland in the 1960s and turning it into office parks.
fact2: Peery, who dropped out of the Stanford MBA program, had gained early experience managing his father's small property portfolio.

name: Oprah Winfrey
fact1: Oprah Winfrey has transitioned her hit talk show into a media and business empire.
fact2: Winfrey parlayed her role as a news anchor into a 25-year talk show gig. Reinvested, the profits from her show add up to nearly $2 billion.

name: Chase Coleman, III.
fact1: Chase Coleman started out as a hedge fund investor, but his Tiger Global Management has evolved into a broader investment firm.
fact2: Coleman's Tiger Global hedge fund has a long record of delivering fantastic returns.

name: Doris Fisher
fact1: Doris Fisher cofounded clothing retailer Gap in 1969 with her husband, Don (d. 2009), after the couple struggled to find jeans that fit him.
fact2: The couple raised $63,000 to open their first store, which sold jeans and music, in San Francisco.

name: Noam Gottesman
fact1: Noam Gottesman cofounded hedge fund GLG Partners in 1995, which started out as a subsidiary of Lehman Brothers.
fact2: GLG went public in 2007 and was sold to Man Group for $1.6 billion in 2010. Gottesman stepped down as CEO at the time of the sale.

name: Jimmy Haslam
fact1: Jimmy Haslam is the CEO of Pilot Flying J, a truck stop company founded in 1958 by his father who paid $6,000 for an existing gas station in Virginia.
fact2: In October 2017, Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway announced it would acquire 39% of Pilot for a reported $2.7 billion and then another 41% by 2023.

name: Drew Houston
fact1: Drew Houston is the CEO of Dropbox, a file sharing service that has more than 500 million users.
fact2: Houston cofounded the company in 2007, when he was 24, with MIT classmate Arash Ferdowsi.

name: James Irsay
fact1: Jim Irsay owns the Indianapolis Colts, the NFL team he inherited from his father, Robert Irsay (d. 1997).
fact2: He grew up with the Colts, living with the team during summer camp and traveling on the team bus.

name: Bradley Jacobs
fact1: Most of Bradley Jacobs' fortune comes from XPO Logistics, a commercial transportation company that ships heavy goods like washing machines to homes.
fact2: Jacobs created XPO Logistics in 2011 and has expanded it with some $8 billion in deals; he owns just under 14% of the NYSE-listed company.

name: Sean Parker
fact1: Sean Parker's fortune stems from his brief tenure, at age 24, as Facebook's president.
fact2: Parker is now a venture capital investor and philanthropist.

name: Penny Pritzker
fact1: Penny Pritzker is one of 11 billionaire heirs in the Pritzker clan, and the only one who has served in the White House.
fact2: A key fundraiser for President Obama ahead of his election, Pritzker was the U.S. Secretary of Commerce from 2013 to 2017.

name: Phil Ruffin
fact1: Phil Ruffin owns the Treasure Island Hotel & Casino plus 50% of the Trump International Las Vegas hotel alongside friend Donald Trump.
fact2: Son of a grocer, Ruffin dropped out of college to sell hamburgers with his buddies, then used the profits to buy convenience stores.

name: Thomas Secunda
fact1: Thomas Secunda is a cofounder of financial services and media company Bloomberg LP.
fact2: He built the company's financial products, most notably its lucrative terminal business.

name: E. Joe Shoen
fact1: Joe Shoen is the president and chairman of U-Haul's $3.6 billion (sales) parent company Amerco, where he has a 21% stake.
fact2: His parents L.S. and Anna Mary Shoen cofounded the truck and trailer rental company back in 1945.

name: Warren Stephens
fact1: Stephens Inc., his Little Rock investment bank, was founded by his uncle Witt in 1933; his father Jackson joined in 1946.
fact2: The outfit underwrote Wal-Mart's public offering in 1970.

name: Mark Stevens
fact1: Silicon Valley venture capitalist Mark Stevens was a partner at Sequoia Capital when the firm invested in hits like Google, PayPal and LinkedIn.
fact2: Now he is investing in startups through his firm S-Cubed Capital.

name: George Argyros & family
fact1: The grandson of Greek immigrants, Argyros worked his way through high school and college in southern California as a paperboy and grocery clerk
fact2: Argyros, a real estate mogul, founded property firm Arnel & Affiliates in southern California in 1968 and currently serves as the CEO.

name: Ray Davis
fact1: Ray Davis and fellow billionaire Kelcy Warren founded natural gas distributor and pipeline company Energy Transfer in 1995 and built it into a giant.
fact2: Davis stepped down as co-CEO in 2007 but still owns 6% of the listed company.

name: John Paul DeJoria
fact1: John Paul DeJoria is the founder of tequila maker Patrn Spirits Co. and cofounder of hair care company John Paul Mitchell Systems.
fact2: He slept in his car and sold shampoo door-to-door before he teamed up with Paul Mitchell in 1980 and turned $700 into John Paul Mitchell Systems.

name: Bennett Dorrance
fact1: Grandson of John T. Dorrance, the inventor of the famous canned soup formula, Bennett Dorrance owns a 15% stake in Campbell Soup Co.
fact2: Dorrance is a founding partner of DMB Associates, a real estate development firm with projects in Arizona, Utah, California and Hawaii.

name: Phillip Frost
fact1: A long-time health care investor, inventor and founder, Phillip Frost now runs diagnostics-maker Opko Health.
fact2: In September 2018 the SEC accused him of participating in a "pump-and-dump" scheme that generated over $27 million from unlawful stock sales.

name: John Henry
fact1: After acquiring a fortune in the early 1980s from his trading firm J.W. Henry & Co., John Henry started building a sports empire.
fact2: Henry and his partner Tom Werner bought the Boston Red Sox in 2002 for $380 million and delivered the Sox' first World Series win in 86 years in 2004.

name: Stephen Mandel, Jr.
fact1: One of Julian Robertson's "Tiger Cubs," Stephen Mandel started his hedge fund firm, Lone Pine Capital, in 1997.
fact2: As of January 2019, Mandel will no longer manage investments for his Lone Pine Capital but will remain a managing director.

name: Jorge Perez
fact1: Jorge Perez runs Related Group of Florida, which claims to have developed more than 80,000 condos, mostly in Miami, since it was founded in 1979.
fact2: As a young urban planner, Perez met developer Stephen Ross, which led to a partnership. Today Ross' affiliate Related Companies owns a 25% stake.

name: Jeff Rothschild
fact1: Jeff Rothschild owes his fortune to Facebook, which he joined in 2005 as the VP of infrastructure engineering.
fact2: After five years as the VP, Rothschild took on an advisory role, and left Facebook in June 2015.

name: T. Denny Sanford
fact1: T. Denny Sanford owns First Premier Bank, which specializes in offering credit cards to high-risk borrowers.
fact2: The Sioux Falls-based bank has just 12 branches, but is one of the largest issuers of Visa and Mastercards -- many with steep rates and low limits.

name: Ty Warner
fact1: Ty Warner is the creator of Beanie Babies, the plush toy fad of the 1990s.
fact2: Warner now gets a chunk of his fortune from his high-end-hotel portfolio, which includes the Four Seasons in New York.

name: Anita Zucker
fact1: Anita Zucker is CEO of Charleston, South Carolina-based InterTech Group, a private, family-owned chemicals manufacturer.
fact2: InterTech was founded in 1982 by Zucker's late husband, Jerry, who died of a brain tumor in 2008 at age 58.

name: John Arrillaga
fact1: John Arrillaga built a fortune in Silicon Valley real estate.
fact2: Arrillaga partnered with Richard "Dick" Peery, buying farmland in Silicon Valley in the 1960s and turning it into office parks.

name: Bill Austin
fact1: Bill Austin owns Starkey Hearing Technologies, the largest hearing aid manufacturer in the U.S.
fact2: He bought, a hearing aid parts shop, which was then called Starkey Labs, for $13,000 in 1970.

name: Lee Bass
fact1: In 1959 Lee Bass and his three brothers inherited $2.8 million each from oil tycoon uncle Sid Richardson.
fact2: The brothers parlayed their inheritance into multi-billion dollar fortunes with the help of bets on oil that paid off big.

name: George Bishop
fact1: George Bishop founded GeoSouthern Energy in 1981.
fact2: In one of the biggest scores of the oil boom, GeoSouthern sold its south Texas fields to Devon Energy for $6 billion in 2013.

name: Timothy Boyle
fact1: Timothy Boyle dropped out of the University of Oregon in 1970 to help his mother rescue their fledgling family company, Columbia Sportswear.
fact2: The family business started as Columbia Hat Company in Portland, founded in 1938 by Boyle's grandparents, who had fled Nazi Germany for the U.S.

name: Joseph Grendys
fact1: Joseph Grendys runs Koch Foods, a poultry processor that slaughters, ships and sells chicken under its own brands and through private label products.
fact2: The $3.2 billion (estimated revenues) business makes buffalo wings and chicken strips for Walmart and nuggets for Burger King.

name: W. Herbert Hunt
fact1: One of 15 children (by three women) of legendary oil wildcatter H.L. Hunt.
fact2: With brother Nelson Bunker Hunt (d. 2014), he tried to corner the world silver market until the price of the metal collapsed 80% in 1980.

name: Eric Lefkofsky
fact1: Eric Lefkofsky made his fortune from the daily deals site Groupon, which he founded in 2008 with longtime business partner Brad Keywell.
fact2: Lefkofsky remains Groupon chairman, but spends the bulk of his time running healthcare startup Tempus, which uses data to improve cancer treatment.

name: C. Dean Metropoulos
fact1: C. Dean Metropoulos is best known for saving the iconic Twinkies and Hostess Brands.
fact2: Metropoulos and private equity firm Apollo bought the shuttered company in 2013 and later took it public.

name: Bob Parsons
fact1: Colorful founder of GoDaddy, Bob Parsons sold off his remaining stake in the  web hosting firm and continues to reinvest the proceeds.
fact2: Parsons first sold a majority stake of GoDaddy in 2011 to private equity investors KKR, Silver Lake and TCV. The firm went public in 2015.

name: John Pritzker
fact1: John Pritzker learned the hotel business at his family's Hyatt Hotel chain; he sold his shares in Hyatt to relatives in 2010.
fact2: Pritzker went on to build Commune Hotels and Resorts, a boutique hotel management company, which after a merger in 2016 became Two Roads Hospitality.

name: Peter Thiel
fact1: PayPal cofounder Peter Thiel became a venture capitalist and early investor in Facebook.
fact2: He also cofounded CIA-backed big data startup Palantir, recently valued at $20 billion; his estimated 10% stake makes up two-thirds of his wealth.

name: Alan Trefler
fact1: The son of a holocaust survivor, Alan Trefler used to work as a teen at his father's small furniture business.
fact2: In 1983, at age 27, he started Pegasystems, a software company that focuses on streamlining business and enhancing customer engagement.

name: Jerry Yang
fact1: At Stanford, Yang earned a B.S. and M.S. in electrical engineering, then dropped out of a Ph.D. program to found Yahoo with David Filo in 1995.
fact2: Yang served as Yahoo's CEO but stepped down in 2009 after turning down an acquisition offer from Microsoft. He left Yahoo's board in 2012.

name: Denise York
fact1: Denise York owns an estimated 90% of the San Francisco 49ers, one of the most valuable teams in the NFL.
fact2: The value of the team, estimated at $3 billion, increased following the 2014 opening of a new $1.2 billion stadium 40 miles south of San Francisco.

name: David Zalik
fact1: David Zalik is the cofounder and CEO of financial technology company GreenSky.
fact2: The Atlanta-based company has facilitated $13 billion in loans for home improvement projects via a network of banks and 13,000 contractors.

name: Edward Bass
fact1: In 1959 Edward Bass and his three brothers inherited $2.8 million each from oil tycoon uncle Sid Richardson.
fact2: The brothers parlayed their inheritance into multi-billion dollar fortunes with the help of bets on oil and pipelines that paid off big.

name: Norman Braman
fact1: Norman Braman owns one of Florida's largest car dealerships, Braman Motorcars, with six locations and more than $2 billion in annual revenue.
fact2: Braman made his first fortune retailing vitamins and drugs, but now sells BMWs, Porsches, Rolls-Royces, Hondas and Hyundais in Florida and Colorado.

name: Chuck Bundrant
fact1: Chuck Bundrant is the chairman and cofounder of Trident Seafoods, the largest vertically integrated seafood company in North America.
fact2: Today the $2.6 billion (est. sales) harvests, processes and markets frozen and fresh seafood and has operations in China, Japan and Germany.

name: Kenneth Feld & family
fact1: Kenneth Feld owns live entertainment company Feld Entertainment, the parent company of Disney on Ice, Monster Jam and other shows.
fact2: Feld Entertainment grew out of Ringling Bros. circus, which was shut down in May 2017 due to falling ticket sales.

name: David Gottesman
fact1: David "Sandy" Gottesman's fortune mostly comes from his early investment in Berkshire Hathaway, on whose board he sits.
fact2: A Harvard Business School graduate, Gottesman co-founded the investment firm First Manhattan Co., which was an early investor in Berkshire Hathaway.

name: Brad Kelley
fact1: Brad Kelley, a Kentucky native and a farmer's son, built a fortune from discount cigarettes.
fact2: He built Commonwealth Brands, maker of USA Gold and Malibu cigarettes, and sold it for $1 billion in 2001.

name: Daniel Pritzker
fact1: Daniel Pritzker is one of 11 billionaire heirs in the Chicago-based Pritzker family, whose best known creation is Hyatt Hotels.
fact2: Pritzker has been working on a film, Bolden!, a biographical drama about New Orleans trumpeter Buddy Bolden, on and off for a decade.

name: Alexander Spanos & family
fact1: Alexander Spanos, the longtime owner of the San Diego Chargers, died on October 9 at the age of 95.
fact2: Spanos bought his controlling stake in the Chargers in 1984. His grandchildren John and A.G. run the team, worth $1.9 billion net of debt.

name: Vincent Viola
fact1: The son of a truck driver from Brooklyn, Vincent Viola started electronic-trading firm Virtu Financial in 2008 and took the company public in 2015.
fact2: Virtu bought one of its speed-trading rivals, KCG Holdings Inc, for $1.4 billion and completed the merger in June 2017.

name: David Walentas
fact1: David Walentas founded Two Trees Management, which is best known for transforming two Brooklyn neighborhoods, Dumbo and Williamsburg.
fact2: Walentas owns 20 residential and commercial properties across Dumbo, Brooklyn Heights, Williamsburg and Manhattan.

name: Ron Baron
fact1: Ron Baron is the CEO of Baron Funds, a money management firm he founded in 1982; it has over $30 billion in assets under management as of August 2018.
fact2: The buy-and-hold investor defended his bet on Tesla in September, predicting he'll make 20 times his money by 2030.

name: Rakesh Gangwal
fact1: Airline veteran Rakesh Gangwal made his fortune from InterGlobe Aviation, the parent outfit of budget airline IndiGo, India's largest by market share.
fact2: Gangwal started his airline career with United Airlines in 1984 and went on to run US Airways Group as its chief executive and chairman.

name: Thomas Hagen
fact1: Thomas Hagen is chairman of Erie Indemnity and has been a part of the company for more than 40 years, including three years as CEO from 1990 to 1993.
fact2: The publicly-traded insurance company was cofounded by his late wife Susan's father, H. O. Hirt, and his friend O. G. Crawford.

name: Osman Kibar
fact1: Osman Kibar is the founder and CEO of biotech firm Samumed.
fact2: Samumed said it raised $438 million in August 2018 to further its work developing drugs to reverse aging, claiming a valuation of $12.4 billion.

name: Thai Lee
fact1: Thai Lee is CEO of $8.5 billion (2017 sales) IT provider SHI International, which has 17,000-plus customers including Boeing and AT&T.
fact2: Born in Bangkok, Lee grew up in South Korea and moved to the U.S. for high school.

name: Drayton McLane, Jr.
fact1: Drayton McLane turned his family's grocery distribution company, McLane Co., into an international firm and sold it to Walmart.
fact2: McLane became president and CEO of the company and ran it for almost 30 years, averaging a yearly sales growth of 30%.

name: Bobby Murphy
fact1: Bobby Murphy cofounded social media app Snapchat, which debuted as Snap Inc. on the New York Stock Exchange in March 2017.
fact2: Snapchat lets users share disappearing messages or photos and videos with captions, masks and filters.

name: H. Ross Perot, Jr.
fact1: In 1988 Perot founded Hillwood, his real estate development company.
fact2: On 18,000 acres of pasture outside Fort Worth, Perot's Hillwood built AllianceTexas, an "inland port" and logistics center.

name: Stewart Rahr
fact1: Stewart Rahr expanded Kinray, a pharmaceutical distributor his father founded in 1944 and sold it to Cardinal Health in 2010 for $1.3 billion in cash.
fact2: Rahr is known for his extravagant lifestyle, which he funds through conservative investments in private equity, hedge funds and natural resources.

name: J. Joe Ricketts & family
fact1: Online stock trading pioneer Joe Ricketts founded brokerage firm Ameritrade four decades ago in Omaha, Nebraska and took it public in 1997.
fact2: His company acquired TD Waterhouse for $2.9 billion in stock and cash in 2006 and renamed itself TD Ameritrade.

name: Larry Robbins
fact1: Larry Robbins is founder and CEO of Glenview Capital Management, a New York hedge fund that oversees over $8 billion in assets.
fact2: Robbins is known for his hot and cold streaks. He posted double-digit returns in 2017 after losing money the previous two years.

name: Evan Spiegel
fact1: Snapchat creator Spiegel became one of the youngest public company CEOs at age 26 when Snap began trading in March 2017.
fact2: Each day some 191 million people use Snapchat to send disappearing messages;  the app faces growing competition from Facebook-owned Instagram.

name: Pat Stryker
fact1: Pat Stryker is a philanthropist and founder of Bohemian Foundation, which supports communities through music, the arts and civic programs.
fact2:
The healthcare heir has given $185 million to charity over her lifetime, primarily
through her Bohemian Foundation.

name: William Young
fact1: William Young is CEO of $2.7 billion (sales) plastic container maker Plastipak.
fact2: Young and his father founded Plastipak in 1967, shortly after Bill graduated from the University of Detroit Mercy with an engineering degree.

name: Todd Christopher
fact1: A high school dropout, Todd Christopher founded hair care products company Vogue International in 1987.
fact2: Christopher sold a 49% stake to the Carlyle Group in 2014 and 51% to Johnson & Johnson for $3.3 billion in cash in June 2016.

name: James Clark
fact1: Jim Clark cofounded Netscape but has since multiplied his wealth through timely tech investments.
fact2: The former Stanford professor got in early on Apple, Facebook, Twitter, and Palantir.

name: Steve Conine
fact1: Steve Conine is cofounder and co-chairman of online home goods retailer Wayfair.
fact2: He started the business in 2002 with Niraj Shah, a fellow billionaire. The two met as high school students at a summer program at Cornell University.

name: Jim Coulter
fact1: Jim Coulter is co-CEO and founding partner of private equity giant TPG, which has $84 billion in assets under management.
fact2: Coulter met his longtime business partner David Bonderman while working for billionaire Robert Bass. The pair left in 1992 to found TPG.

name: James Dinan
fact1: James Dinan founded York Capital Management in September 1991 and is the Chairman, CEO and a Managing Partner of the firm.
fact2: In 2014 Dinan purchased a minority stake in the NBA's Milwaukee Bucks, partnering with fellow financial investors Marc Lasry and Wes Edens.

name: Alec Gores
fact1: Alec Gores founded private equity firm The Gores Group in 1987, which has acquired 110 companies and has $2 billion in assets as of June 2017.
fact2: Gores and his younger brother Tom, also a billionaire, immigrated to America from Israel with their parents and four other siblings in 1968.

name: Vinod Khosla
fact1: Vinod Khosla is the founder of Khosla Ventures, a Silicon Valley venture capital firm, and a member of the 2018 Midas List.
fact2: His firm, Khosla Ventures, invests in experimental technologies such as biomedicine and robotics.

name: Aerin Lauder
fact1: Aerin Lauder, the eldest daughter of billionaire Ronald Lauder, serves as style and image director at cosmetics firm Estee Lauder.
fact2: Lauder has worked for Estee Lauder, founded by her grandmother, since 1992. She served as a board member from 2004 to 2016.

name: Clayton Mathile
fact1: In 1970, after ditching his job as an accountant at the Campbell Soup Company, Clayton Mathile became employee number six at pet food maker Iams.
fact2: Mathile bought the whole business in 1982, when it had $13 million in sales. The big payday came in 1999, when P&G acquired it for $2.3 billion.

name: Niraj Shah
fact1: Niraj Shah is cofounder and CEO of online home goods retailer Wayfair.
fact2: He started the business in 2002 with Steve Conine, a fellow billionaire. The two met as high school students at a program at Cornell University.

name: Kavitark Ram Shriram
fact1: An early Google backer, Kavitark Ram Shriram has sold of most of his stock but remains on the board of its parent company, Alphabet.
fact2: Born in India, Shriram studied math at the University of Madras. After moving to the U.S. he joined Netscape in 1994 as an executive.

name: Dan Snyder
fact1: Dan Snyder initially made his fortune with a marketing business, Snyder Communications, that he started as a college dropout.
fact2: After taking the company public in 1996, Snyder sold it to French company Havas for $2.5 billion in 2000.

name: Ted Turner
fact1: Media-mogul-turned-land-baron Ted Turner grew his father's advertising firm into Turner Broadcasting and founded the Cable News Network (CNN) in 1980.
fact2: He sold Turner to Time Warner for $7.3 billion in stock in 1996 and, after Time Warner bought AOL in 2001, saw his fortune tumble as shares dropped.

name: Elaine Wynn
fact1: Dubbed the "Queen of Las Vegas," Elaine Wynn became the largest shareholder of publicly traded Wynn Resorts in March 2018.
fact2: Her ex-husband and cofounder Steve Wynn cashed out entirely and stepped down as CEO amid sexual harassment allegations, which he has denied.

name: Jon Yarbrough
fact1: Jon Yarbrough started Video Gaming Technologies, which makes casino games, in 1991.
fact2: Business grew due to the proliferation of tribal casinos; Yarbrough says he's worked with around 35 tribes in more than 100 locations over the years.

name: S. Daniel Abraham
fact1: S. Daniel Abraham founded Slim-Fast in 1976. Sales exploded in the late 1980s when former LA Dodgers manager Tommy Lasorda became its spokesman.
fact2: Abraham sold the weight loss and meal substitute company to Unilever for $2.3 billion in cash in 2000.

name: Leslie Alexander
fact1: In September 2017 Leslie Alexander agreed to sell the  Houston Rockets NBA team to Tilman Fertitta for $2.2 billion, 25 times what he bought it for.
fact2: Alexander paid $85 million for the Rockets in 1993, just before Hakeem Olajuwon led the team to NBA titles in the next two seasons.

name: Ben Chestnut
fact1: Chestnut founded what later became Mailchimp with Dan Kurzius in 2001 as a side project to their web design company.
fact2: Mailchimp's email marketing software for small businesses garnered enough customers that in 2007 they committed to it full time.

name: Alexandra Daitch
fact1: Alexandra Daitch owns an estimated 3% stake in Cargill, the largest food company in the world.
fact2: She's one of four billionaire sisters who inherited stakes in the company from their father W. Duncan MacMillan, who died in 2006.

name: Glenn Dubin
fact1: Glenn Dubin is the founder of Engineer's Gate, a quantitative trading hedge fund, comprised of 76 employees including 25 PhDs.
fact2: Dubin's fortune comes from Highbridge Capital, which he cofounded in 1992 and then sold to JP Morgan Chase in 2004.

name: John Farber
fact1: John Farber is the longtime chairman of ICC Industries, which trades basic and specialty chemicals. It also holds a controlling stake in Frutarom.
fact2: In May 2018, Frutarom was sold to International Flavors & Fragrances for $7.1 billion.

name: Frank Fertitta, III.
fact1: Frank Fertitta III and his brother, Lorenzo, made the bulk of their fortune through mixed martial arts promoter UFC.
fact2: The brothers bought UFC for $2 million in 2001; it sold to an investment group led by WME/IMG for $4 billion in 2016.

name: Lorenzo Fertitta
fact1: Lorenzo Fertitta and his brother, Frank, made the bulk of their fortune through mixed martial arts promoter UFC.
fact2: They bought UFC for $2 million in 2001; an investment group led by WME/IMG bought it for $4 billion in 2016.

name: Gordon Getty
fact1: Gordon Getty led the sale of his family's Getty Oil to Texaco for $10.1 billion in 1984, after his oil tycoon father J. Paul Getty died in 1976.
fact2: Once the sole trustee of the family trust, Getty orchestrated the breakup into six separate trusts in 1985.

name: Dan Kurzius
fact1: Kurzius founded what later became Mailchimp with Ben Chestnut in 2001 as a side project to their web design company.
fact2: Mailchimp's email marketing software for small businesses garnered enough customers that in 2007 they committed to it full time.

name: Chris Larsen
fact1: In 2012, Larsen cofounded Ripple with Mt. Gox founder Jed McCaleb to facilitate international payments for banks using blockchain technology.
fact2: Prior to that he cofounded online mortgage lender e-Loan in 1997 and in 2005 cofounded Prosper, a peer-to-peer lender.

name: Jeffrey Lurie
fact1: Jeffrey Lurie is a former college professor but he's more widely known as the outspoken owner of the Philadelphia Eagles NFL team.
fact2: In 1983, Lurie took an executive role at General Cinema Corporation, the film company founded by his grandfather.

name: Sarah MacMillan
fact1: Sarah MacMillan owns an estimated 3% stake in Cargill, the largest food company in the world.
fact2: She is one of four billionaire sisters who inherited stakes in the company from their father W. Duncan MacMillan, who died in 2006.

name: Phillip T. (Terry) Ragon
fact1: Phillip Ragon, known as Terry, founded InterSystems, a software company that enables hospitals and banks to analyze big data, in 1978.
fact2: Ragon retains full ownership of the company, which had $644 million in 2017 sales.

name: Antony Ressler
fact1: Antony "Tony" Ressler cofounded private equity giant Apollo Management with brother-in-law and fellow billionaire Leon Black in 1990.
fact2: Like Black, he had previously worked at Wall Street firm Drexel Burnham Lambert, where he was known for his role in the bond department.

name: Lucy Stitzer
fact1: Lucy Stitzer chairs Waycrosse, the investment company of the Cargill and MacMillan families, one of the 10 richest clans in America.
fact2: Stitzer owns an estimated 3% stake in Cargill, the largest food company in the world.

name: Katherine Tanner
fact1: Katherine Tanner owns an estimated 3% stake in Cargill, the largest food company in the world.
fact2: She's one of four billionaire sisters who inherited stakes in the company from their father W. Duncan MacMillan, who died in 2006.

name: Ronald Wanek
fact1: Ronald Wanek is the founder of America's largest home furniture manufacturer and retailer, Ashley Furniture.
fact2: He started his first furniture manufacturing business, Arcadia Furniture, in 1970 with a loan from his father and money he got from selling his home.
